151236934.review:
I was in the mood for a good cry and this delivered 10/10. The game itself is a point and click adventure that runs about 3 hours with another hour-ish of optional DLC if you want some more meta knowledge of the series universe, Overall I thought the storytelling and aesthetics were great; I'm not a huge fan of point and click adventures, but this is a good exception and I'll probably play through the next episodes of the series at a later date. If you're looking for other games in this vein, I feel like the Edith Finch team probably drew a lot of inspiration from this as "What Remains of Edith Finch" has very similar vibes and gameplay.

Side Note: If like me the achievement didn't log at the end of the game for you, know that you can get it by switching to the beta version of the game in properties, and then reloading the last scene from your last autosave (make sure the language is set to English for this).

150254881.review:
Really doesn't deserve the hype for two main reasons. First, the story actually is very weak. Second, I knew to expect no gameplay but you still have to interact with the game quite a lot to move it forward and that part sucks terribly here.

People are crying over a love story full of massive plot holes, zero character depth and no love expressed between the characters. They have nothing together and shouldn't have been together in the first place. It didn't move me or affect me deeply in any way.

The dev bamboozled the players and possibly even himself with time travel, recurring items that symbolize things (every artsy fartsy movie director's favorite) and a few table spoons of confusion. It gets praise in part due to the way the story is told in that it keeps the player guessing despite being told backwards - and that IS clever - but in terms of tying everything together correctly the ball is dropped pretty hard and right from the start of the game too, confusing you through no fault of your own. Even though half of it made no sense, in the end the game plays sad piano music, the normies start crying and presto: best game ever. Puhleaze.

Autism spectrum disorder could and should also have been represented better with a lot more care. Players unfamiliar with it may well get the wrong idea.

I had to google how to progress at one point despite having been trying to do exactly what the game wanted me to do to progress, but it hadn't worked because of the bad interface, leading me to waste my time repeatedly re-exploring the area with the belief that there must have been something else to find. The game puts you on a horse with no ability to dismount. Then to be able to click an NPC to progress you have to get right on top of him, horse and everything and click in just the right spot. Movement in general is awkward. You frequently have to click the same object 6 times in a row, this is by design. Obviously that's bad design. The game will make you wait a second after every click before the next click can be registered. Why not let the player hold the button down instead of clicking over and over?

I did appreciate the overall creativity, the beautiful piano music, the witty dialogue and you do get the sense that the dev tried to get the most out of RPG Maker, creatively going as far as for example portraying a day/night transition where the sky turns red when the sun comes in. In a game with a 3D engine the engine can generate the lighting transition for you in realtime. In this case you have to appreciate that it's done with hand made pixels.

Later in the game however, the dev takes getting the most out of RPG Maker XP a few steps too far. While the story builds, so does the frustration. A confusing looping action sequence with enemies, floor spikes to avoid and 'shooting' is thrown in, something that the engine isn't suitable for, causing a climax in the frustrations just before the actual story's climax where it does the most damage. It felt out of place in a game that outside of this part is like a walking sim all the way through.

There's no settings and that's bad because the music is so loud and the graphics are too pixelated for fullscreen that it defaults to. You have to figure out on your own to press Alt+Enter to switch to windowed mode and the window you then get is far too tiny. You then drag the window's edges to make the game an acceptable size. When you relaunch the game it's back in fullscreen mode and after Alt+Enter the window is tiny again.

I don't always necessarily [i]regret[/i] playing a game that I write a negative review for. In this case I do and I wish I could get my 6 hours back. The majority of Steam users are casuals with low end systems and on average they are suckers for easy to play games with a "cutesie" 2D art style that will run on a potato. That factors into the overall rating quite a bit. If what you're looking for is a story that'll make you cry then pick up Highway Blossoms. It kicks like a mule compared to this.

After finishing To The Moon I thought: "What the hell, dev.... did I miss something here?". Looking for the answer to that question I found this video uploaded 5 years ago. Huge spoilers so only watch it after you've played if you're still interested in playing. 
https://youtu.be/67npeQIRVLU
I didn't miss anything. The one on the left is an actress who is generally more emotional and emotive than I am and probably has higher emotional intelligence. She gets really into social dynamics between characters in games, yet her experience in To The Moon matched mine pretty much exactly. She speaks my mind with every single point she makes including the ones I didn't write about. I just understood more quickly that what the game was trying to portray with one of the main characters was autism.

There is a lot to be desired in the quality of life. The movement is slow, some scenes are drawn out, gameplay and direction is not always clear, and the plot takes some time to develop.

However, when you get near the end, around the 2.5 hour mark, there is a beautiful explanation for all of the loose ends, tying up everything beautifully. Even somewhat expecting what to come, there were lines that hit me like a freight train, rupturing the plumbing near the eye sockets.

It's a beautifully written story with a really lovable ending that is well worth the time invested. I'm not spoiling anything. This is a masterpiece.

149968364.review:
I remember watching Markiplier playthrough of this back in the day. Back then, I was taken aback by how good the story was. 

I decided to buy this game and its next 2 installments (which I am yet to play so I will reserve the right to change my opinion on this depending).

My thoughts are:

- Gameplay - RPGMaker just does not produce an interesting gameplay, and this game is another example of this. Gameplay heavily requires story to do the carrying. Gameplay is also fairly linear, you do get 'hey, you gotta do this soon or bad things are gonna happen' but it does not feel said bad thing will ever happen.
- Music - I thought it was excellent throughout, they capture feeling of melancholy and dread well through out the game, and I did get anxious when the 'dreadful' music would start.
- Storytelling and story - Admittedly, story had significantly less impact on me than it did back when I watched the playthrough. I like the job the main characters have, and it still feels as somewhat unexplored topic, which was certainly much more the case back when the game came out. The main love story is touching, albeit I preferred the real thing over the 'wish' in the end. 

Overall: I think it is a good story, worth exploring in case you are one of the rare people not to go through it already. In case it does not move you, I do not think there is enough left to make you enjoy it.

149915212.review: No game, upon its completion, has made me feel as disappointed and as enraged as To The Moon. What was supposed to be an emotional journey through an old man's memories to fulfill his final wish turned out to be a horribly offensive and inconsistent story that isn't subtle about its hatred. There isn't much gameplay, but I didn't mind that as the focus of the game is supposed to be on the story. The tone is all over the place. It aims to be a heartbreaking game, but the constant unfunny commentary from the two main characters (one of whom makes blatantly sexist remarks to his partner throughout the game) ruins any tension the game would otherwise build. This is one of very few games that features an autistic character (the game never directly tells you she's autistic, but it's heavily implied), but she is treated as a soulless husk whose abilities and limitations are wildly inconsistent. Every other character treats her as a problem to be solved, so it wasn't surprising to find out the developers have donated to Autism Speaks which is considered by autistic people to be a hate group. This game boasts its representation of neurodivergent minds but strips its character of her autonomy and turns her into an animal to be studied and ogled, and these are dangerous stereotypes that real autistic people already have to fight. I don't think any real autistic person was involved in the making of this game. I really wanted to like To The Moon, and the glowing recommendations and reviews I saw made me think that I would, but its disgusting sexism and autistic rep make me hate this one. I won't be recommending it to anyone, and I will be trying to remove it from my memory.

149112408.review: When I completed To The Moon, one of the first things that I noticed was simply how underwhelmed a lot of people seemed to have felt with it. If such be from the puzzles being bad, or the story simply not being enough to touch them; and to those I can two things. First it is true that the story wont touch everyone, as while I thought is was a fantastically moving piece, I can understand some situations, or real life events/feelings that could lead an individual in a direction that this story will simple not touch. Things of which I believe are 100% okay, not everything is made for everyone and that is okay. The second point I have however is in the puzzles. To which I need to say that those are not the point. To The Moon does not need to have fantastic puzzles. If I am being fair I was surprised when the "puzzles" that are in the game came up, because I really did not expect anything like them at all. Something I can say because I believe that To The Moon should not be understood as a typical game perhaps, but a interactive book. A sentiment I can hold simply from one of the first thoughts I had when playing the opening section to the game. A moment wherein I  stopped and thought "Wow, this game is almost like a visualisation of what it feels like to read a book, and imagine what I am reading in my head." because it truly does, and I am not sure if this is perhaps just my own personal experience, but the design, colours, music, everything, perfectly recreated a no-imaginary feeling of thinking about what I books words would look like. With the only difference being that fact that I could control and characters in the book, and could use them as a outlet for my emotions regarding the path set out for me. A feeling even stronger then that of which I have had with any other interactive media ever. Regardless however, I do understand that not everyone will feel that same regarding this game as I did, which is fine. But as for my personal take, I think To The Moon is brilliant, and one of now two pieces of media in my life that have truly made my cry. I felt sew attached to its story, and hope that people who are hesitant just give it a try. For the soul reason that they may find one of their favourite games as well.

148253195.review:
Horrible gameplay.  Most of the gameplay is walking around clicking on things. And even then the controls are pretty bad. You'll hit dead ends and have trouble finding the things with the bad controls and muddy graphics. There's also a really bad side scrolling section and some easy grid puzzles as well.

The story is extremely basic and straightforward. I expected a whole lot more subtlety for a game with this kind of reviews. You barely know the characters at all and have no reason to care about them or the things that happen. Johnny and River have about 2 minutes of game time together. They meet, say some cliched dialogue, and then they're basically married. That's it. Not exactly that broken up this amazing relationship might not happen. Something bad happens in his past but again you don't really care because it barely effects these characters you don't even know. Johnny has some friends and there's a housekeeper that you might also think have some significance but they are totally irrelevant to the story. The 2 player characters have the majority of the dialogue and mostly just spout out really bad quippy dialogue out of fan fiction.

The music I liked in several parts. That's definitely the highlight.

Controller support is there but it is not good. Especially for the side scrolling section and a game of whack a mole.

I completed it in 2 hours. And I thought "that's it?". Not worth toughing out the horrible gameplay for the story. Just read a synopsis. For a game in 2011 this would have been better.. But big waste of time in 2023+.

147409407.review:
So.... I just finished the game, I bought it because all of the reviews were really good and I'm a fan of indie pixel games, so I thought that I'd definitely like it 1000%... but I felt kind of underwhelmed, not saying the game is "bad" in the slightest though. 

Hmm.. the soundtrack is nice, and it did trigger some emotions for me while playing it.. but for me it was just the gameplay that really messed up my experience, maybe it's just because I'm not used to point and click type games but I swear whenever I'd click stuff to navigate the map sometimes the character would just NOT move until I started spamming a few times. The puzzles were fun though.
Also, the game just kept kept FREEZING it was so sad, and at some point my game crashed a few times and assets wouldn't load. I was playing the game while the background/floor tiles weren't loading and I was just walking around thinking that the ground was deliberately meant to disappear lol, I was thinking "man... isn't the floor meant to be made out of grass? where's the grass?".

In terms of the story.. it was interesting, it wasn't a BAD story, it was good! Just a little bit boring.. Like, I felt like I could understand what was going on, but I just couldn't get too invested even though I tried really hard to like it as much as I could. The characters were okay, I couldn't get too connected to them either because they didn't feel "interesting" enough but I think that's just personal preference. (Neil pissed me the fuck off lmao, but he was annoying in the funny way so I guess he's my favourite in this game.. he's a silly billy in a good way.)

I saw a lot of people say that they cried during this, but I didn't feel emotional enough at the end of the game to really start sobbing - and I'm the kind of person that cries over eeeeverything, so I shocked myself with that!

Overall, I'm really sad to say that I didn't like this game as much as I thought I would. I feel like the only thing I can say about it is that it was "okay", I don't regret buying and playing it though! It was a nice experience and I always like playing things made by indie developers... but I think it just wasn't my cup of tea, or coffee (reference to the game har har). Maybe the crashing and buffering just made me too annoyed to really immerse myself into the game, maybe if it didn't do that I would've enjoyed it more but alas... 

Pretty ok game!

145887670.review:
I just have to say that this developer became one of my IMMEDIATE favorites. The price tag is well justified and I would encourage anyone who likes a great story to jump on this one - and the others (Finding Paradise, A Bird Story, and Imposter Factory) IMMEDIATELY. This is a series you NEED in your library.

The thing that makes these titles so special is the fact that they're very thoughtful and have complicated storylines, and they run the gamut of content - from light and funny, to dark and serious, to hopeful, heart-broken, upset, happy, and everything in between. This series is one of those that when you start one of the games, you just won't be able to stop until it's finished, and each one has a lot of content/story. Once you start playing, you'll be gripped by it and just HAVE to know how things turn out.. and you'll probably sit there playing until it's done. AMAZING, AMAZING stories.

Basic concept (which, I don't think this will be a spoiler, but I'll hide it anyway): [spoiler] Ever had something you know you're going to regret on your deathbed? Maybe you wish you had done this thing, or made that choice. Now your life is over, and you're regretting how things turned out. What if there was a way to truly believe you HAD done that thing or made that choice? The company Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene work at does just that - on your deathbed, they burrow into your memories, find out what makes you tick, and implant a series of new memories into your head - overwriting the old memories - so that as you pass away, you do so happy with the way things turn out.[/spoiler]

The great thing about each story is diving into it, figuring out what makes each character tick, finding out all about them... and it's told in such an amazing way. I can't tell you enough how fantastic this developer is at telling stories.

My recommendation is to play them in order. While each episode is a "self-contained" episode, it really benefits the player to play them in order. Kinda like how if you watch different episodes of your favorite TV show... sure, each show might be a self-contained story, but you don't get the full context unless you watch them in order.

To The Moon
Finding Paradise
A Bird Story
Imposter Factory

Some folks might disagree and say A Bird Story should come before Finding Paradise, since it sorta comes chronologically before FP... But one of the things that makes each story great is "getting to know" the people involved... and I feel like "A Bird Story" is better viewed as the "deleted scenes" of a movie, rather than as a prequel. If you watch the deleted scenes on a DVD first, maybe it won't "spoil" the movie, but it just doesn't feel right. Play FP first, and then dive a little deeper with ABS.

Get all 4 of these immediately. This is one of the few storyline games that got me a little choked up. I absolutely LOVE the characters and every bit of these stories was phenomenal. I couldn't possibly recommend them any more. They are well worth the full price. I had... SO much fun, and I am ANXIOUSLY awaiting the next chapters from this developer. STUNNING story. Easy gameplay. VERY... very moving.

145751349.review:
this is none other than a conceptually flawless piece of eye candy through a linear layout like a movie that was also extremely difficult to finish. 

no-- it wasn't difficult to finish because it's a 'pixel game' or whatnot. it was difficult to finish because of how close it comes to a slice of life through the theme exploration of trauma, loss, and chosen life.

"... since the market crashed" is quoted by one of the misc. characters in the third eldest flashback of john's life. it's safe to assume that this game takes place in the period that it was released (early 2010's) because of the technology and cars used, but the architecture of john and river's mansion is very timeless (and beautiful) , as is the dialogue and dynamics each of the characters have.

[u] there are details i'd like to un-orderly jot; [/u] 

  - the red and black squirrels chasing each other. black squirrels are invasive to red ones in north america and this causes quarrels between them.

  - both of the researchers dr. rosalene and dr. watts contrast each other well (i'd date both of them tbh), the entirety of their interactions are very conversational and the scenes that lack one and has the other feel empty :,)

  - initially, i thought that some of the mementos' symbols could have been more versatile. i thought 'why include the stuffed platypus multiple times?' until i realised it was a harmonious symbol to river. it is criminal to (spoiler) not include the stuffed platypus at NASA... but... i get it... make the game more serious, the finale, blah blah :,D

  - the scene where (partial spoiler, foreshadowing) dr. watts and rosalene saw their first rabbit roadkill and watts said "you know it's a great wedding when the memento is roadkill / maybe it's a metaphor to how rotten the marriage was years later, or something equally pretentious" this was great, lol

  - the scene when (partial spoiler) john and river were sitting and watching the moon together the night of the carnival. "at least you don't have a name like *john*. that's everyone's name." "even india?" "probably!" correct me if i'm wrong, but i was told growing up that the most popular names in the world for about a decade were muhammad (indian-muslim) and john. it was like, like western people thought the world's most popular name was john because of ethnocentrism or something and it's always been debunked to be muhammad. maybe i'm just looking into this too much

as per the storyline once again, the concept of 'canon events'... this game is really ahead of it's time for that as they've been popularised in movies in recent years. not only do i think it is ahead of it's time... 'to the moon' seems to have inspired some aspects of the hit indie game 'stardew valley'. the sprite of younger john's head, the size of the elevator, the proportions of the people to the buildings etc. are uncanny. MY FAVOURITE, THOUGH: the flower barrel in the high school art class!!! is that not *exactly* the spring barrel in stardew?!

edit: reiterating on the 'this is hard to finish' note i made. with trauma your brain blocks out memories and i totally get that sometimes. it's not even fuzz, like, you try to avoid symbols of that memory altogether and john's two first chronological memories being blocked capture this really well. especially since this wasn't generally known information by typical people in ~2012.

the ending to this game is unreal. freebird games: AS YOU SHOULD making a separate dlc for the soundtrack because the soundtrack is extremely clean cut and professional. what really was a kicker at the end when [spoiler] watts and rosa were watching john and river go off into space and the spaceship sounds merged with the heart monitor, until you realised that the heart monitored flattened. personally this moment wasn't even sad, really, that was magnificent. [/spoiler]

145216267.review:
this game compelled me to write my very first review, just to give you a perspective of how *good* this is. i almost regret buying the bundle on sale because it deserves full price

to the moon is a very simple game, with easy plot to follow and puzzles to solve. most of the gameplay is point-and-click and reading dialogue. however, the story will destroy you. the premise is very original: you play as two scientists traversing through a dying man's memories to fulfill his one last wish. it WILL punch you where it hurts, and the accompanying beautiful soundtrack puts you even deeper into the story. the pixel art is also breathtaking.

the two scientists Eva Rosalene and Neil Watts are charming protagonists, who like to banter and exchange one liners left and right. Neil is a king of comedy and i love him; Eva's cynical retorts and one-liners are also great. they give an interesting image to this game's worldbuilding; they are largely sympathetic and react to what they see in the memories, but also have seen similar lives a hundred times before, causing them to sometimes appear apathetic to what we see. they try to keep things professional and they quickly move on from memory to memory, which I find is a really fascinating character trait.

anyway, play the game and prepare for the feels. i dont recommend if you want any sort of action or fights; this game is very story-focused and has zero action (barring rising suspense of figuring out Johnny's life and wish). bring tissues. or ice cream, for after you finish it
(also holy crap there is so much content, there are so many sequels and minisodes and there are apparently comics and plushies--)

144599444.review:
Introduction:

In the labyrinth of interactive narratives, "To the Moon," an opus by Freebird Games, emerges as a luminary constellation, weaving a symphony of emotions through its masterfully orchestrated narrative and minimalist gameplay. This review embarks on a meticulous exploration of the game's multifaceted layers, unraveling the delicate interplay of storytelling, mechanics, and design that establishes "To the Moon" as a seminal gem within the genre. While it beckons players to traverse the poignant corridors of memory, it's imperative to illuminate both its resplendent virtues and the occasional shadows that mar its brilliance.

Narrative Poignancy and Aesthetic Prowess:

Freebird Games' visual opus underscores its minimalist aesthetic with an indomitable narrative prowess. The pixelated vistas serve as a canvas for the multifaceted emotions and nuanced characters that populate "To the Moon." The pixel art, seemingly modest, conceals a wealth of detail that underscores the theme of reminiscence and the dreamlike quality of traversing memories.

The game's narrative luminary is a tale of profound resonance, interwoven with themes of love, loss, and the irreversibility of time. The character arcs are meticulously constructed, evolving with an elegant subtlety that reverberates long after the final credits. While the narrative gambit of "To the Moon" revolves around rewriting memories, it is the authentic and emotional undercurrent that catapults this endeavor into a realm of timeless storytelling.

Mechanical Subtleties and Evocative Gameplay:

The gameplay of "To the Moon" is an understated orchestra, wherein the symphonic mechanics resonate in harmony with the narrative's emotional cadence. The core conceit of navigating backwards through a character's memories is an ingenious fusion of exploration and puzzle-solving, leveraging the interactive medium to yield an introspective journey.

The puzzles, albeit not overly demanding, mirror the sentiment of traversing memories – a blend of familiarity and enigma. They manifest as interludes within the broader narrative symphony, never overshadowing the storytelling's primacy. However, some players might find these puzzles somewhat simplistic, a quirk that underscores the narrative's predominance over gameplay intricacy.

Audio Enchantment and Musical Alchemy:

Music, in "To the Moon," transcends mere accompaniment, becoming a character in itself. Kan R. Gao's spellbinding composition maneuvers with graceful precision, punctuating the emotional crescendos of the narrative with melodic resonance. The minimalist piano-centric score is a testament to the transformative power of music in eliciting emotions and embedding players within the narrative tapestry.

The soundscape, nuanced and sensitive, resonates deeply with the game's emotional core. The sounds of rain, lapping waves, and rustling leaves entwine with the music, forging an auditory realm that amplifies the immersive experience.

Pacing and Narrative Rhythm:

While "To the Moon" luxuriates in its deliberate pacing, it could present an occasional hurdle for players seeking a more kinetic experience. The introspective exploration of memory warrants patience, allowing the narrative's emotional reverberations to permeate the consciousness. Yet, this narrative luxury might deter players seeking a more immediate engagement.

Furthermore, while the game's narrative tugs the heartstrings with grace, there exist moments where dialogue seems forced, temporarily suspending the immersive illusion and grounding players in a sense of self-awareness. This occasional discordance, though minor, merits acknowledgment within the tapestry of the overall experience.

Conclusion:

"To the Moon," a symphony composed by Freebird Games, converges interactive mechanics, narrative acumen, and emotional resonance to craft an ethereal odyssey through memory's labyrinth. Its minimalist artistry, soul-stirring narrative, and evocative score stand as testaments to the potential of games as a medium for storytelling. While its gameplay is intentionally unobtrusive, its mechanical subtleties dance in harmony with the overarching narrative cadence.

The game's journey, though basking in its deliberate pacing, might not harmonize with players seeking rapid gratification. Nonetheless, "To the Moon" is an exceptional testament to the artistry and emotional potency of interactive storytelling. Its narrative and themes transcend time, weaving a celestial narrative tapestry that persists as a beacon of the medium's potential for poignant, introspective exploration.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing To The Moon. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

So I beat this game all the way back in 2015 and I uh, kind of remember it? I'm gonna try to review it based off knowledge from long ago.

[b] Story:[/b] so there is this dying guy who really wants to go to the moon and these two scientists (whom you play as) work to make his dream come true by going through the memories of his life and trying to control his actions so he eventually goes to the moon.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]  so I think there were some puzzles in here or something? you find core memories and have interactions that (hopefully) lead to this guy going to the moon, there is a lot of talking in it. personally I thought the gameplay was just okay for what's there. [b]Conclusion:[/b] It's a pretty good time and if you like sad stories but also happy ones at times you should have fun. by the end I was thinking about what I would want to do if these memory people were real and stuff, I'd probably ask them to send me through a wormhole or make me a grilled cheese. 143712707.review:
[h1]Fly me to the Moon[/h1]
[i]This game is heavily story focused, thus the review will try reflect that[/i]

To the Moon is an indie adventure RPG developed by Freebird Games and released in 2011. On the surface, the game appears simple - the retro graphics, straightforward point-and-click gameplay, and lack of action or combat don't hint at anything profound. However, To the Moon delivers one of the most emotionally impactful stories in gaming through its brilliant narrative, multifaceted characters, and exploration of complex themes.

[h2] Pros and cons [/h2]
[table]
[tr]
[th] 🟩 Positives [/th]
[th] 🟥 Negatives [/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]
- Emotional, well-written story and characters that made me cry many times

- Beautiful soundtrack that enhances the storytelling

- Unique premise of traversing memories to fulfill a dying man's wish

- Charming pixel art visuals that match the nostalgic tone

- Thought-provoking exploration of themes like love, grief, regret, and meaning
	[/td]
	[td]
- Gameplay is very limited, mostly just dialogue and basic point-and-click

- Puzzles are simple

- Short playtime of around 4 hours

- Some technical issues like resolution

- No options menu
	[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]	

[h2]Story[/h2]
At first, the premise seems straightforward - Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts exploring Johnny's memories to implant a fabricated one. But an incredibly moving romance emerges as players slowly uncover the tragic history between Johnny and River.

We start at the story's tragic conclusion, Johnny's unfulfilled wish to go to the moon before death. Working backwards heightens the mystery and creates natural dramatic irony as players know Johnny's fate before learning what befell the couple. As they explore his past, a tragic love story unfolds. In his youth, Johnny met River, a blunt but charming woman with Asperger's syndrome. Though their personalities clashed, they fell desperately in love. But when River fell ill, refusing treatment, Johnny constructed a house by a cliffside lighthouse hoping to fulfil River's dream.

[h3]Story Structure[/h3]
The game only reveals Johnny and River's backstory in fragmented snippets, parsing vital details through memory flashbacks. Interacting with meaningful objects like Johnny's mementos or environments from his past provides satisfying detective work piecing together his relationship with River.

[h3]Character Design[/h3]
[b]Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts[/b]
On the surface, Eva and Neil seem like insensitive doctors just doing their job. But as the story progresses, glimpses of their personality shine through. Neil uses humour to cope with the problematic nature of his work. At the same time, Eva tries to remain professional but can't help getting invested in their clients' lives. Their cynical banter gives way to quiet reverence as Johnny's tragic story leaves them profoundly impacted.

[b]Johnny and River[/b]
At first, Johnny seems like a curmudgeonly old man longing for his lost love. But through the memories, we learn he has a quiet tenderness beneath his gruff exterior. Meanwhile, River's Asperger's makes her logical and literal. Still, she has an astute emotional intelligence, knowing the right things to say to comfort Johnny when distressed. Their quirks complement one another, making an unlikely but perfect pair.

[h2]Music[/h2]
The serene piano chords especially move during memory scenes as players explore poignant remnants of Johnny's past. These contemplative pieces evoke nostalgia and longing, transporting us into Johnny's mindset as he reflects on happier times with River.

Meanwhile, the subdued technological sounds accompanying present-day investigation scenes nicely reflect the scientists' clinical, emotional detachment as they routinely purge dying peoples' memories. Yet slight warmness breaks through at moments, hinting that even the jaded doctors are invested in Johnny's plight. Finally, the ending song "Everything's Alright" provides a bittersweet closure, combining gentle piano with lyrical vocals and strings. 

[h2]Art Style[/h2]
Visually, To the Moon adopts a straightforward 16-bit graphics style. Sprites move stiffly through flat, low-detail environments. However, this primitive aesthetic complements the emotional narrative rather than detracting.

The visual simplicity creates an ironic contrast with the story's sophistication. Johnny initially appears as a stereotypical grumpy old man but secretly harbours profound romantic devotion. The doctors look detached but care deeply. The deceivingly emotive pixel art style embodies the dissonance between superficial appearances and inner complexity.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
"To the Moon" utilises its interactive medium to tell a resonant tale of love and loss through its unconventional reverse chronological story structure, melancholy soundtrack, and deceptively nostalgic pixel art visuals. The game proves that superior writing, music, and thematic intent can sometimes surpass bleeding-edge graphics and mechanics in creating a compelling gaming experience. "To the Moon" delivers an unforgettable interactive narrative that stays with you long after the credits roll.

141741767.review:
(Mild Spoilers) This game is terrible. Not only are the controls clunky, the characters obnoxious, and the gameplay tedious at times, but it's also grossly ableist. It's made very clear that River is autistic, but the game never even uses the word "autism" and makes it seem like it's a bad word. They keep referring to it as "her condition" and going on and on about how hard it is for her husband, John, to tolerate her. Mind you, these two are supposed to be in love. He explicitly refuses to learn about her "condition" when given the opportunity, and also makes it clear that he only started going out with her because she was "weird" and "unique" and he didn't want to be "boring" so he uses her to make himself appear more interesting.

I found out after playing that the creator has donated to Autism Speaks in the past. It seems he has since learned about the criticisms against Autism Speaks and no longer supports them. I think it's great that he acknowledged his mistake in supporting them, but he still has a lot to learn about autism. It's clear that he did not reach out to the autistic community during the development of this game.

It's very problematic, and honestly even if it wasn't, it's still a terrible story. It tries to be funny, then romantic, then heartbreaking, then creepy, round and round again, failing at each. By the end of the game, I hated all but a few side characters and River. I felt little more than annoyance during my playthrough. The ending was so unsatisfying, and there were a few loose threads that are never acknowledged (perhaps in a sequel but I'm not sticking around to find out).

I did enjoy the soundtrack and the visuals, and I liked the idea of going through someone's memories in reverse order. The main premise sounded really interesting and could have been done very well. I typically love games that involve facing the reality of death and questions of morality. This one, however, was a miss. I would not recommend this game to anyone.

141344427.review:
I bought this game for $1.22 on the summer sale and still regretted it.
I'm really confused by the overwhelmingly positive rating. I was fully ready to get invested and cry, but the beginning did not pull me in.

I don't like the crunchy, over textured art style with generic sprites and even blander close-ups.
I personally hated the music. It's generic. Seriously don't get the hype. It feels like something a soulless corporation would make for a sad pandemic advertisement. It sounds like default music you'd find when downloading RPG maker.
There's no options to adjust anything in the game. It's way too loud, and the flashing lights hurt my eyes. The walk speed was also a pain.
The writing is REALLY BAD. I could forgive everything else in the game if it wasn't so painful to read through. The dialogue between the two main characters was cringe. They talk like middle schoolers. Their personalities consist of being snarky and sarcastic despite them being clumsy with their actions. It's truly confusing seeing how they are both professionals. I knew I wasn't going to be able to finish the game if I had to read their interjections the entire time.
Only the atmosphere was good. 

This is the most bland "dramatic", "sad" story ever. It's not even bad enough that it circles around to being good. It's just not interesting.
If you're still wanting to buy this, just go watch a YouTuber play it instead.

140295671.review:
To the Moon is an extraordinary game that takes you on a deeply moving journey through the depths of human emotions. From the moment you start playing, you'll find yourself completely immersed in a story that unfolds with heartfelt sincerity and remarkable depth.

Visually, To the Moon is a work of art. The pixel-art graphics are thoughtfully designed, evoking a sense of nostalgia while allowing the characters and environments to come alive with an undeniable charm. The attention to detail in every pixel creates a visually immersive experience that seamlessly complements the emotional depth of the story.

While the gameplay mechanics are relatively simple, it is the story that takes center stage in To the Moon. The focus is on exploration and unraveling the intricate layers of the characters' lives. It's a testament to the game's brilliance that it can convey such profound emotions without relying on complex gameplay mechanics.

In the end, To the Moon is not just a game; it's an experience that transcends reality. It's a poignant reminder of the impact we have on one another and the importance of cherishing every moment we have. If you're seeking a game that will touch your heart and leave an indelible mark on your soul, To the Moon is an absolute must-play.

139243968.review:
A touching and bittersweet story, told in a way you don't see everyday.

You help a dying man fulfill his last wish, to get to the moon by entering his memories. 
Similarly to the movie Memento, you start at the end of the story and work your way to the beginning.
Things will happen that might seem mundane or meaningless but by the end of it, you'll understand why characters did what they did or how some felt during specific moments (there were moments that brought me close to tears when I realized how characters truly felt during some scenes).

Accompanied by a soundtrack that has already found a spot in my playlist and a great set of main characters that you want to learn more and more about, I can't recommend this game enough.
I literally completed this game in one sitting, the story and characters just sucked me into this little world and wouldn't let me go until it was over.

139181235.review: Just completed this game, and my god....it put me on a roller coaster of emotions, which I absolutely wanted and mainly look for in video games these days. It's a heartfelt storyline about love, jumping timelines, loss and grief, and connecting with people from various stages. Can I just say firstly though, I freakin' love Neil Watts (aka Dr. Watts)! His corny jokes and witty humor help lift up the mood where it's needed, and his lines certainly made me chuckle! Anyway, without spoiling the video game plot, I will simply say....it is like Pixar's 'Inside Out' mixed with that 'About Time' movie (the one with Rachel McAdams in it); you get into someone's mind and you go through a series of events back and forth, trying to link one to another, and gathering pieces of evidence here and there to overall form this main part of the video game (which involves a man's passion for space and the moon), all while dealing with various people's different emotions. Definitely have a tissue or two by your side though if it tugs at your heartstrings. To finish this off, just imagine someone or a group of friends you've met along the way - it is crazy that if a certain event never happened, you wouldn't have met them, and a love or friendship wouldn't have occurred. Mind-baffling, right?

139043740.review:
I am not particularly sure how to describe this game since it has been a while since I've typed any honest review which didn't consist of like, one word. This is just not that type of game, but I feel like I should write on it.

To the Moon is, much like the description of the game says, a story about two doctors (very lovable doctors at that) traversing through a dying man's memories via a special machine. While this is the in-universe explanation as of how you do everything that you do, I think this game is way easier explained by thinking of it as some sort of time travel, mainly because it heavily relies on the Butterfly Effect. The smallest change your characters make will entirely affect the grand image.

At its core, To the Moon, and its sequels which I am admittedly yet to touch are walking simulators, so if you are here for fire gameplay then this is probably not for you - but then again if you are looking at 16bit indie games i don't believe you're looking for fire gameplay anyway. What To the Moon will provide to you though, is a bittersweet, incredible story in the quickest form there is, with the experience not taking any longer than four hours.

Overall, the Sigmund Corp series seem to have incredible pieces of music, top-notch story in each and every game, and two of the most lovable indie game characters out there. Very cool, would ride horses because my partner is stupid again.

138639055.review:
The narrative was well crafted and the characters were relatable and well developed. The only issue I had with the game (*or maybe the narrative-rpg genre?) is the lack of variety in gameplay. 

The game had two main actions: 
1. exploring the map and interacting with artifacts and NPCs 
2. finding mementos that trigger past memories.  

I feel like RPG games in general fail to give players autonomy in the narrative. Many games like To the Moon tend to rely on dialogue-based story telling instead of incorporating the narrative in the game environment itself and letting players figure things out themselves. There had been many instance where I felt like the explanatory dialogue made the game "too easy" and gave me no challenge as a player. In my opinion, it would have been better if I had discovered that piece of information through game artifacts or through other means. Games like in IB and Yume Nikki succeed in telling complex stories through the use of interactive items and environmental storytelling and do an excellent job at involving players in "piecing the story together". I am not saying that To the Moon should have followed the structure of those games, but I feel like a similar gameplay structure could have added more challenge and excitement to the players. 

With that aside, I enjoyed the banter between Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts and found myself quite attached to those two when I finished the game. I felt like these two characters being there really helped brighten up the overall vibe of the game (***would just be a REALLY sad story w/o the two).

I also loved the soundtrack by Kan Gao and the songs by Laura Shigihara. The OST helped me create a bigger emotional connection to the game and immersed me in the story. 

Overall, I'd say it is a great short game to play. I would definitely recommend giving it a try.

138632254.review: A charming pixel art candy shell, with a delightful center comprising of a poignant expedition of emotional symphony!

138596910.review:
Number 1: I'm a big burly manly man with a beard, pot belly, and strong feelings about professional wrestling. Number 2: I knew what was coming and was expecting to be hit in the feels. Number 3: I tend to overthink, and assumed that because I was now expecting to be hit in the feels, I would no longer be hit in the feels. Number 4: I was most definitely wrong. 

This game was just absolutely lovely from start to finish. Right now, I'm also playing Hogwarts Legacy and even though I have 70 hours on that game versus about 6 on this, I will remember To the Moon much more vividly. It is the perfect balance between excitement, emotions, and humor. Know from the start that every moment is important. Think of it like a book and take your time. 

I will say that prior to playing I read reviews where the writer was disappointed in not feeling anything. I don't think the bar is very high, but you must be the type of person who enjoys (and understands) symbolism. I'd recommend watching the Pixar short Float if you have any doubts, and if you are not struck in your big squeeky center, then this game is not for you. 

I'm also just going to add that I am a Psychiatrist (okay... so I may have left that out when talking about my burliness). Although never stated directly, Autism is very well represented in this game. It never judges and also presents both sides of what can happen including the downsides of social training (and benefits). It is not over the top and I would not call it a mental health or Autism specific game, but it was nice to see representation done tactfully. 

I am soooooo soooooooo soooooo glad I got the bundle with everything including comics. This is a top notch writing crew and I know my fragile ticker is in good (and sometimes cruel) hands.

ADDENDUM: After writing the initial review, I felt compelled to read negative reviews. The main argument appears to be that this is not a game and the format it is presented doesn't contribute to the experience. My response (since no one asked for it) is this. 

Question 1: Is this a game? 

Answer 1: Yes. Specifically, there is basically only 2 game elements. The first asks you to find important objects in a pixel setting. This largely involves either using your keyboard to walk around a scene or your mouse to hover over items looking for icon changes. Is it a masterwork in game design? No. Does it serve its purpose? Yes (more on this in question 2). The second game element is actually a rather fun puzzle presented after finding the aforementioned important items. They give you an unimportant, but still enjoyable challenge of letting you know how few clicks an ideal solve would involve. This permitted me to sit and think through 6 or so steps in my head prior to solving the puzzle. Not for everyone, but I enjoyed this as a game element by itself. That said, LET ME BE CLEAR... the game elements are very clearly secondary to the narrative. Know what you are getting... it is not Halo, Tetris, or Mario. In those games, gameplay is first while narrative second (except for Tetris which is the perfect balance between both). This is clearly story over game, and as long as you know that you are in for a cozy read with interactive elements and puzzles to break up the experience, you will have a lovely time. 

Question 2: Does it being a game add anything to the experience? 

Answer 2: Yes. By actually having me engage with the environments and think about what may be important about each item highlighted, I was able to connect much more strongly than if I just watched someone play on YouTube or if it had been a movie/graphic novel. If I had been presented with story... story... story (meaning without any pauses for the game elements), I think I would have not had time to stew on what was being presented. I suppose you can read a graphic novel page or watch a video and take pauses here and there to reflect, but I personally would likely never do that. The creators use those elements to pace the experience and enhance engagement. For me, it wholeheartedly worked.

This game has reminded me that I am not a robot and I can feel. Great and emotional storytelling. It is really difficult to express your feelings just in words, but Freebird Games did it flawlessly by mixing them with gorgeous visuals and a mesmerizing soundtrack.

For some reason, one of the best quotes in film history was floating in the back of my mind for the most part of the game: "...All those moments will be lost in time, like tears in rain..." said by Nexus-6 replicant Roy Batty in one of the best sci-fi movies ever made - Blade Runner. I am guessing it is because you are aware of what is coming all along, but ultimately that is not the most important thing, as Dr. Eva Rosalene said, -"The ending isn't any more important than any of the moments leading to it.". So, keeping those words in mind, I recommend playing this game from beginning to the end, because the journey to the moon...or any other place where you can reconnect with the loved one is all that matters.

137984178.review:
The story in this game is pretty good. It starts off odd, slowly explains some parts and then hits you with a couple of emotional twists. I got the feeling as it progressed that this story could make a very good book or movie.

*However* it does not make a good top-down side-scroller that looks like it was made in RPG Maker 2010.

The gameplay lets this game down so hard that I'm amazed it still has such fantastic reviews. I was so extremely bored within the first couple of hours of playing that I almost gave it up. I'm a parent without any other games to play when my kids are sleeping, so yeah I almost chose just staring at the wall or going to bed early instead of playing this. Movement, like other top-down dated RPGs, is slow, with no environment to look at while you yawn your way to the next screen. The graphics are what you'd expect to have seen 15 years ago, but I guess people just call that "indie" these days. The "puzzle" that you have to solve is repeated, over and over, and you can't avoid it if you want to progress the story. It's not a clever or new kind of puzzle. It's just the same one, getting slightly harder each time, over and over.

The dialogue, and especially jokes, included in this game are ridiculously cringe-worthy. I'm not sure how the devs created such a decent story when they don't seem to know how actual humans interact. This detracted from the story so much that it was almost completely ruined. If the story hadn't been as good as it was (in the end, anyway), then the game would be absolute garbage. Thankfully the story carried this game and raised it up to simply a slightly memorable waste of time instead.

I usually love games in this genre, but normally they have some kind of atmosphere that actually helps tell the story instead of hinders the experience. Take Stories Untold, or Outer Wilds for example. Both very good games with deep, intricate stories which are [i] enhanced [/i] by the engaging gameplay. I'm not sure if anyone ever told the devs of TtM that games were meant to have at least some discernible level of fun.

I cannot actually recommend this game to anyone, unless you have a bunch of time to kill with nothing else to do, and for some reason you actually like mind-numbingly boring gameplay with a single repetitive puzzle thrown in.

Go read someone's synopsis of the story instead, there's gotta be some people out there with decent writing skills that are willing to type it up.


Oh yeah... and [spoiler] the Anya thing is so bloody stupid. Sure she thought they were stars when she was a kid, but she's an adult now. Letting herself die for it is insane and not a "cute mental health thing" as they tried to dress it up as. [/spoiler]

137748155.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- As an RPG Maker game, it isn't much to look at. Sure, it'll give you those fun SNES vibes, but it's not a visual buffet even by those standards
- The music, however, is really enjoyable. It provided a nice background layer throughout

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- The story is really well done. The entire concept of implanting false memories to grant a dying wish is a fascinating idea and a philosophical can of worms, but I like how the main game sets that aside to tell you a sad story about an old dude who wishes he would have been an astronaut
- The world building is excellent, especially if you play the two bonus episodes. As you may expect, society seems a little iffy on the concept of the technology Drs. Watt and Roselene are peddling
- The actual dialogue is a bit of a letdown. It's got that forced wackiness to it in some points that really just comes off as trying too hard. It's a shame that it kinda takes the shine off of an otherwise fantastic narrative

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- It's an adventure game, so you're mostly just walking and talking. The central gameplay loop (finding items to power a portal to the next memory) doesn't really have much appeal other than advancing the story
- Thankfully, there is a little variety. There's puzzles from time to time, and the game throws a few loops at the player like having them chase down people on a horse or avoid computer zombies

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- I'm pretty sure you could run this on anything
- Although it played well on the Steam Deck, I'd recommend just playing it on a mouse and keyboard. There's one part that requires WASD and the arrow keys, so if you're using the M+K controller layout, that's mapped to the left stick and d-pad. It felt pretty awkward

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]7/10[/b]. I loved the story and world-building, but I wish the dialogue didn't make me roll my eyes so much. Still, it's work a playthrough if the plot devices sound cool to you

137420175.review:
The focus is the story - and it shows.

Interaction primarily comes from walking around an area map, speaking with NPCs and examining objects.  This exploration can be slow and is often limited to only a handful of places and people, with very few side areas and 'secrets' to uncover.  At some points a puzzle mini-game will crop up - while not difficult (unless perhaps going for the 'perfect' score) these do little to add to gameplay.  There are only a few moments of player choice in the dialogues, and they have little to no impact on the story as a whole.  

Simple, clean, and well-animated pixel art and sprites are able to express emotion and setting well - there is never a question of 'what is that?' when looking at the various assets.  A beautiful mix of piano and vocals are the main leads for the amazing soundtrack, with other fantastic sound design scattered throughout.

All theses criticisms and praise are connected to the same central point - they tie directly to the story.  

The people and objects that are available to interact with show and flesh out the main characters, showing their struggles and joys bit by bit.  The puzzles are there for a narrative reason, and offer a reward of another clue towards deeper insight.  The moments of choice allow the player to chose what window of perspective they want to view that moment in time from.  The music and sounds highlight key points and directly add to the plot.  The art is simple as to not distract from what should be the focus. 

Because the story is the heart of this game, and it beats strong.  The emotion is incredible, both for the characters and players.  It is human and relatable, without shying away from the harder parts of life and celebrating the beauty of the better moments.  It is also willing to pose unique questions, theories, and philosophies, if one looks closer and examines the nuances and undertones of the dialogues and actions. 

This is an experience best done organically and untainted by spoilers, so it is hard to say much more, but an exceptional narrative should make the audience feel, think, and question what is within.   To the Moon does just that.

Not really sure why this game is so beloved. It's a story-driven RPG maker game with no combat, which isn't a problem. I like these games when well-executed. This one is not well-executed. The two main characters are very annoying and often crack jokes or make weird comments that take away from the emotionality of the story. Even ignoring that, the story feels like it forces its twists and key emotional moments through really contrived plot elements. Spoilers contain more details but obviously spoil the whole game. [spoiler] The mother using beta blockers to remove the main character's memories of his dead brother is absolutely bizarre and nonsensical, and his wife's refusal to talk about his memory loss and how he forgot their first meeting directly is equally as baffling and frustrating. She spends much of the game trying to indirectly remind him and getting upset when it doesn't land. The game seems to want to use her autism as a reason for why she doesn't ever bring it up directly but it doesn't make any sense for her demonstrated level of social function and just comes off as kinda insulting, painting her as childish and sometimes rude. [/spoiler] A tearjerker game with emotional dissonance in many places and poor setups for poor twists. 

Not recommended.

137082716.review:
To The Moon is a game that will touch your heart in ways you never thought possible. At its core, it's a story of love, loss, and the power of memories. But what sets it apart is the incredible connection between the two main characters, scientists Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts.

From the moment you meet them, it's clear that Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts have a relationship that goes beyond just being coworkers. They finish each other's sentences, they bicker like an old married couple, and they have a level of trust and understanding that can only come from years of working together. It's a joy to watch them interact, even as they're dealing with the heavy subject matter of the game.

But what really makes the connection between these two characters so special is the way their stories intertwine. As they explore the memories of a dying man, they're forced to confront their own pasts and the choices they've made. And through it all, they're there to support each other, to pick each other up when they're feeling down, and to remind each other why they started this journey in the first place.

Watching these two characters grow and change over the course of the game is a truly beautiful experience. They start as two strangers brought together by a job, but by the end, they've become something more - friends, partners, and maybe even something akin to family. And it's all thanks to the way their stories are woven together, creating a tapestry of memories and emotions that will stay with you long after the game is over.

In conclusion, To The Moon is a masterpiece of storytelling, and a large part of that is due to the incredible connection between Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts. Their stories are intertwined in a way that is both poignant and powerful, and their relationship is a testament to the idea that sometimes, the people who help us through the toughest times in our lives are the ones we least expect. If you haven't played this game yet, do yourself a favour and experience the magic for yourself. You won't regret it.

135621025.review:
[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] Engaging and poignant storytelling
[*] Unique gameplay that combines puzzle-solving and exploration
[*] Well-developed and memorable characters
[*] Beautiful soundtrack that enhances the emotional impact
[*] Deep exploration of human emotions and life choices
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] Graphics might not be everyone's cup of tea, but they have a nostalgic charm
[*] Relatively short gameplay, leaving you wanting more
[/list]

[i]To The Moon[/i] revolves around Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts, who work to fulfill the dying wishes of their patients by creating new memories in their minds. In this story, they help Johnny, an elderly man, achieve his dream of going to the moon. As they delve into his memories, they uncover fragments of his past and piece together a touching story of love, loss, and missed opportunities.

The game is filled with moments that will make you laugh, cry, and feel a wide range of emotions as you learn more about Johnny and his life. The characters are expertly crafted, making you feel deeply connected to them and their struggles.

Honestly, this game affected me so much that one day after playing it, I saw an old man at a local Costco and just started crying. Overwhelmed by emotions, I even offered to take him to the moon, which led to security escorting me out. It's not every day that a game can have such a profound impact on real-life emotions.

So, if you're looking for a gaming experience that will touch your heart and stay with you for a long time, I highly recommend giving [i]To The Moon[/i] a try. Despite its shorter length and perhaps dated graphics, the game delivers a powerful narrative that you won't forget anytime soon.

135582458.review:
The story this game tells is beautifully complex, much like how life is. It avoids cheap morals and instead paints in great detail the tragedies and joys that shape a person's life. The story is also told in a very innovative and intriguing way, with plenty of humor and fun game references along the way. 

Also, the music is really beautiful. And if you're a fan of PvZ music, Laura Shigihara also worked on the soundtrack--you can definitely hear her unique style in some of the tracks (think PvZ but more melancholic and mysterious).

If I had one complaint, it would be that the walking is a little slow sometimes, but the nice BGM makes up for that.

Strongly recommend.

135436677.review:
[h1]Firstly, Who is Kan Gao?[/h1]
Kan Gao is a Canadian game programmer. He started making his first game, "Quintessence: The Blighted Venom" in September 2006. He would go on to make "Do You Remember My Lullaby?" in 2008, an unfinished demo of "Lyra's Melody - The Song She Whispered to Me" in 2009 and "The Mirror Lied" in 2011. Kan Gao would release "To the Moon" a little later on November 1, 2011. He used "RPG Maker XP" as game engine. "To the Moon" would become Kan's the most popular work.

[h1]Story[/h1]
One of the best story games I've ever seen.Sigmund Corporation uses a technology that can create artificial memories. They offer this as a "wish fulfillment" service to people on their death beds. Since these artificial memories conflict with the patient's real memories, the procedure is only legal to do on people without much time left to live. Sigmund Corp. employees Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts are tasked with fulfilling the lifelong dream of the dying Johnny Wyles. Johnny wants to go to the moon, although he doesn't know why. The doctors insert themselves into an interactive compilation of his memories and traverse backwards through his life via mementos. We play the game as Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts.

[h1]Music[/h1]
Musics of the game are really good. There is already a piano scene at the beginning of the game and you hear a lot of "For River". The tracks "Having Lied", "Lament of a Stranger" and "Moonwisher" are also very good. And hold on tight.. Kan Gao composed the music for the game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There isn't much about gameplay, but sometimes when I clicked somewhere, I saw the character go to ridiculous places. The gameplay is not very good. I attribute this to the fact that it's an old indie game, but like I said, it's not a big deal. Already after a while you get used to it.

[h1]In conclusion[/h1]
The game made me sad. One of the best games I've played recently. I probably won't forget the game in the future. I think there are very few games that can convey emotions so well. It's an original story that I have not experienced before. If you're looking for an emotional damage and great music, you're in the right place...10/10

First of all the relationship the main characters have isn’t great, while they both seem to be happy with the arrangement it is more a caregiver/caretaker deal than a relationship. The girl is trying to connect and express herself but because of her disability she can’t be understood. The guy is trying his best to accommodate her but when it is needed most she denies the help for her own selfish and nonsensical reasons.

What is most striking about this game is how nonchalantly they introduce dystopian horrors beyond human imagination as something normal in the future. I’m talking about the idea that doctors can change the entire life of a human being before they die so they can die happy. I would be right there with the protesters from the holiday specials and throw tomatoes.

This is one of those games that sticks with you for a while.

135018211.review:
Short and sweet.

In a mere 5 hours of gameplay, you explore an entire lifetime. Beginning in old age and terminating in your patient's youth, [i]To the Moon[/i] brings you on a journey to give a man his dying wish via patently unorthodox methods. Those methods dig up a tumultuous past and culminate in a hail-mary to succeed.

All the while, making you wonder what "patient consent" really means if you know more about your patient than they do. [i]To the Moon[/i] explores a brilliant concept in a simple medium. Set to a modest soundtrack and accompanied by pixel art visuals, this is more like a visual novella. A novella that will pull hard at your heartstrings, but leave uncomfortable questions. 

I really feel for the main characters in this story - they fill a thankless and downright impossible role assisting a helpless clientele. They champion themselves as righteous, but modifying memories is a curious business whose ramifications - medical, judicial, or just plain ethical - are [i]boundless[/i]. But who among the living advocates for the dying when the dead have so little to say? Tombstones provide no testimonials and crematoriums cannot speak, so who commends you for a job well done?

[i]To the Moon[/i] is a beautiful story with the shell of a game around it. However, its RPG Maker foundation doesn't detract from the narrative, interesting characters, ethical quandaries, or lovable music.

134555140.review:
To the Moon is an experience. Released in 2011, just when indie games were exploding, I had never played anything like it before or since. It's an RPG, but there's no combat. It's kind of a visual novel, but there's some interactivity. The main draw is the story.

You play as two scientists, whos job is to allow dying people to relive their entire lives - and fulfill their dreams - inside their head. Our patient here is Johnny, a man whos final wish is to go to the moon. What follows is an emotional journey full of simple puzzles where we slowly piece together the pieces of Johnny's life. It's a tragic tale, sullied a bit by dialogue that at times can be "cringe", but on the whole the story on display here is nearly unmatched in gaming - maybe because the developer focused entirely on the story in lieu of any gameplay beyond very simple puzzles. This is fine, and exactly what the developer intended, but be warned that this game is more of an experience than a game.

One thing I have to mention is the soundtrack. This game has maybe the best soundtrack of any game I've ever played. I first played it in 2013, and while the details of the game have faded in the decade since, the soundtrack hasn't. I'm not normally one who listens to video game music outside of playing games, but I made an exception for To The Moon. When I first played this game, I downloaded the soundtrack and listened to it for months. Simply incredible.

The developer has released a few games since To The Moon and while none have had quite the cultural impact To The Moon has, they're all similarly well-reviewed and are on my list to play eventually.

133820737.review:
Just finished playing this game with a friend, and i have some thoughts i'd like to share to those who are looking to play this classic RPG Maker title. Unfortunately, a lot of my thoughts on the game will come across as vastly negative. To get this right out of the way: I recommend people play this game and form their own opinion on it. To some, the story and characters may strike a cord, but to others such as myself, they fall flat and leave the story feeling hollow and empty. My issues start with the game's characters. Right off the bat we are introduced to two scientists/doctors who are tasked with delving into an old, dying man's memories to grant him his final wish: to go to the moon. These doctors' personalities are rather quickly established: Dr. Rosalene is a straight-laced individual who seems to have more empathy for the patients compared to Dr. Watts, who is seemingly largely uninterested in the patient's life and affairs and simply wants to get the job done as quickly as possible. These characters' personalities stay consistent throughout the entire game... except for one sequence. For the sake of preserving the story, i will not go into details as to what the sequence im talking about actually entails, but we as the player see a rather drastic change in these two characters' personalities and motives. Rosalene acts as though she doesn't truly care for her patient, and is instead focused only on getting the job done. Watts protests this, as he doesn't want to mess with something their patient clearly treasured. It's hard to see this swap as anything other than a need for conflict and an attempt at deepening these two characters, but it just falls flat. Instead of seeing these peeks behind the curtain and seeing this change as a logical path, it comes out of the blue. My second point of contention is , of course, the way this game handles Autism. The patient's wife, River, is shown to be autistic (as is her friend, Isabelle). Unfortunately, the game seems very dated in its portrayal of Autism, as i found that it danced around the subject as much as it possibly could, preferring to refer to it as "Her Condition" (cue threatening music). River's autism is even used as an explanation for why John even wants to date her in the first place, stating that by dating someone who is different, he feels as though he will be different as well. It is due to this fact that i had difficulty in becoming invested in their relationship. Though i believe John truly came to care about River, it simply became difficult to see their relationship as anything more than something built on lies and John's perceived personal gain. There's another aspect of John's character that feels vastly underutilized, as the scene where this information is relayed takes about 10 minutes to get through and is never expanded upon or explained properly. The message this game attempts to tell is very muddy and unclear to me. I genuinely cannot tell you what this game was trying to get across. My best guess is grief? If that's the case, i wholeheartedly believe that there are games out there currently that explore this theme and message infinitely better. 

TL:DR - This game has unfortunately become quite dated in the years since its release. However, I still recommend giving it a shot and trying it to see if it's for you. If you do decide to try it, i suggest playing it with a friend! It keeps the down-times between events entertaining :)

133789292.review:
Perhaps the game's largest flaw is how lacking it is in the gameplay department. 

It's a very story - focused game, and the sporadic slices of interactivity involve very basic and uninteresting environmental exploration. Yes, certain story beats and dialogue scenes can be very moving, and the music is excellent, but it's not choice - based dialogue; I'm just clicking M1 over and over, to get to the next line. Also, in an experience that's over 4 hours long, the occasionally beautiful dialogue scene isn't enough to consistently engage me.

The story has a sci - fi element of looking through someone's memories (similar to 'Inception, 'Reminiscence' and 'Maniac'), but I don't think the rules or mechanics of this technology were well - explained, and I found the plot hard to follow. This is perhaps the first time I've ever played a game that I felt would actually work better as a film or television show, since it's so focused on story and so light on gameplay. Alternatively, a 'Life is Strange' - style experience may have also been beneficial, with 3D environments and voice acting, where you can properly see the characters' faces, and read their emotions. I found the 2D top - down style unengaging.

Coming back to this game always felt like a chore; the roughly 4 - hour story took me 2 months to finish. Overall, I didn't think its strengths were enough to make up for what I found to be a mostly dull experience.

133661425.review:
This game was a roller coaster of emotions to play, although I feel that may in itself be a massive disservice to how impactful it as a story.

To give a brief synopsis: You play the role of two employees of a company, Dr Rosaline and Dr Watts, who's job it is to give dying people a wish that they desire to see before passing away, this particular story centering around this man, called John, wishing to go to the moon. 

In order to grant this wish however, Dr Rosaline and Watts must travel all the way through John's memories until they reach his childhood to plant the idea in his head to become an astronaut. 

The whole entire journey backwards through his life is full of moments of tragedy, despair, fun, love, all the sorts of things you'd expect from a person's life, with it's various twists and turns all throughout.

This game has a remarkable cast of memorable characters, all with their various quirks and personalities and interests to make them stand out and add to the story in their own unique way.  Some of which result in very funny moments in the game that gives much welcome reprieve from the heavier stuff that this game loves to throw at you.

The soundtrack is beyond beautiful, I'm not lying when I say it practically lives in my head rent-free after playing this.  These pieces do excellent jobs at adding to the scenes they're in, as well as occupy a tab on my browser when I need something to chill to.  When I'm able to, I'll definitely consider supporting the soundtrack with a purchase, I strongly recommend you do too if this OST touched you as much as it did me.

This game isn't particularly long, I managed to beat it after 4 hours of total play, but it's well worth paying £8.50 for this game.  
I'm not ashamed to admit that, despite me personally having a heart made of pure onyx, this game absolutely broke me.  I was in tears by the third hour in.  I'm honestly keen to see how well the next lot of games tugs at my heartstrings in the next episodes of this series.

I've had this game in my library for years. I bought it because everyone says that it is SO GOOD, so I wanted to give it a try.

I finally did because it was the monthly game chosen for a game club I'm in and it was such a disappointment.

Firstly, technical details:
- PC version is 640x480 only. It's a tiny little box on my 4k monitors. I tried to alt+enter full screen it and my monitors wouldn't do it. They just freaked out.
- PC version also didn't get the updates that the Switch and mobile versions have. They are much nicer looking than the PC version.
- Controls feel clunky. 
- Icons occasionally don't relate to the action you're taking.
- With the resolution being so small it could be hard to see memories to find.

Once I got the game actually working I found it pretty dull. The characters all felt the same throughout their lives. The kids felt too old and the older versions felt too young. River may have two medical conditions but they never name them, so it confused me about why her having autism (I assume) was so terrible. 

Once I made it to the end, some things became clear but then the 'contractual agreement' of Neil and Eva pretty much ruined everything for me. I didn't feel sad, I didn't cry, I was mostly just bored.
