I read some negative review for this game stating that the story was fantastic however they couldn't recommend it due to its portrayal of Asperger's Syndrome as "being a hassle" in relationships. It then went into detail about blah blah blah autism isn't bad etc etc.

Me and my father both have Asperger's. I can personally attest to the fact that it has been an extreme struggle for him in the relationship department, ultimately causing two divorces as an indirect result of it. It's something that he's had to work through his entire life, and it's something that I'm likely going to have to work through extensively before I can find something that works as well.

In stark contrast to that other guy, I'd like to thank this game for its fantastic portrayal of the struggles of being in a relationship with someone with Asperger's. It's the only game I've ever seen that's brutally honest enough to do so, and of course as everyone else here says, the story is fantastic and will make you cry. So. 10/10.

132103085.review:
To the Moon is the first game in a three part series of the same name. The game follows Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene as they work with patients to fulfill their desires or correct any regrets they have while on their deathbed. The case in To the Moon follows the life and story of Johnny, a man who wishes to go to the moon but can't remember why. 

Johnny's story starts out as a regular case for Watts and Rosalene as they progress through Johnny's life. That is until they get to early childhood which is cut off and inaccessible. The two figure that the memory isn't needed and that they would proceed with the procedure as follows but unfortunately, no matter what they do nothing seems to be working. When it seems that all hope is lost and they aren't going to be able to help Johnny with his final request they learn new information that could save the day. With time quickly running out, and Johnny in his final hours the two must make one last ditch effort to make Johnny's dream come true.

The art and music that accompanies this somber tale is both light and heavy. It mixes the light-hearted moments of childhood with the somber tones of our darker hours. There isn't a single sound that feels out of place, and each sound adds to the emotions presented by the characters' actions and musical track. The final sound truly ringing out among the final moments of Johnny's life presents both a feeling of relief and great loss. 

Once again the walking speed at times seemed a little slow, and unlike in the second game where all the walking restrictions made sense, there were moments in this game where I thought otherwise due to the larger maps at points. The puzzles in this installment of the series were also fairly easy but could be harder for some due to the nature of them being flip based to reveal an image. Despite this however, I finished 90% of all the puzzles in the minimum moveset possible, and didn't find any one of them to be particularly difficult.

With that said To the Moon is a great starting point in the series, but as someone who has played the series out of order, stands alone as it's own game just fine. The idea of reliving a lifetime at the end of one's life can bring many emotions and feelings to mind. Some of these flowing back to the idea of who's truly capable of deciding who gets to play god, and the ethical nature of an artificial life being the only thing a patient will remember upon death. To the Moon made not have had the emotional impact on me that the second game had, I can see how this title if played by the right individual could evoke incredibly strong emotions. This series is best described as bittersweet. At the end of the day the patient passes with a smile on their face, but you have traversed these people's lifetimes and made artificial changes to create that smile. There is something to be said for the jobs that few appreciate, for those jobs are often the most needed. If you had the chance would you relive life once again despite knowing it would all be artificially created?

132047280.review:
First thing’s first: To The Moon is not a game. I hesitate to call it a “story,” and it certainly isn’t a work of art. Reading the “Overwhelmingly Positive” reviews makes me feel like I’m out of the loop on some elaborate prank to make me feel insane.

Most obvious from the store page; the graphics. They’re RPG maker graphics. Nothing special, but aside from some… questionably drawn scenes, it’s basic pixel art. That being said, the utilization of said pixel art is dull. Everything is bland with drab colors and samey design, which is a huge problem because of…

…the “gameplay,” if you can call it that. Drag your playable character around with awkward, clunky movement controls and click on every random object in a dull room until you find the one insignificant thing the developer decided you HAVE to interact with to progress. While a handful are signposted okay with visual cues that guide you toward them, the vast majority are just senselessly chosen and placed to pad out the already painfully slow pacing of the “game.” In addition to this, there are randomly scattered puzzles, many completely unrelated to the plot and with poorly designed arbitrary solutions (For example, there's a random Animorphs trivia question that doesn't even have the correct answer).

But, let’s be real, none of that matters, right? To The Moon is about the AMAZING story that sets a NEW STANDARD for what games should be, right? Wrong. Wrong in a million ways. There is hardly a story here to tell, despite what the reviews will tell you. The first three quarters of the game is a mindless slog with zero substance and the least likable or interesting characters you will have ever seen. You have the two “witty” scientists who serve only to undercut any even slightly serious tones the game comes close to building. The main character (the old man in the bed, not the playable characters) has zero discernible personality. The main character’s wife, aka the OTHER main character is a caricature of someone with autism; she’s totally incapable of expressing herself in any way (unless the plot calls for it and she all of a sudden does a complete 180), and her whole personality is just being a rude smartass because she has autism; a complete spit in the face to anyone who actually has ASD.

The game is a disjointed collection of the main character’s memories, as he has asked the player to enter his mind and implant fake memories of being an astronaut because he wants to go to the moon. About three hours in, the developer must have realized he’s done absolutely nothing productive with the story, because out of nowhere the final quarter of the game turns sharply into an ending almost completely disconnected from everything else. The last hour of the game is another, faster-paced series of random events, but this time with poorly written and repetitive emotional music playing over it. The game is so desperate to claw an emotional response out of its audience that it’s honestly laughable, and does not earn a single one of its attempted emotional moments, though I assume the general melancholic tone of much of the game is what drives people into thinking it’s deep when it’s really not doing or saying anything at all. 

Overall, the game is just a mess, and has virtually zero redeeming qualities. I cannot recommend it for anyone to be honest, and especially today there are dozens to hundreds of well-written, beautifully crafted masterpieces that respect your time, money, and brain much more than this garbage ever could.

131197108.review:
[b]Beautiful, bittersweet, and thought-provoking.[/b]

To the Moon offered a unique gaming experience I’ll never forget.

The narrative is told in reverse chronological order. As the characters travel to the past, you can gradually piece each memory and decode how everything ties to the present. That moment of realization is a powerful, pivotal part of the game.

To the Moon has been on my wishlist for years. At least five people have recommended it to me, and they all said it was a tearjerker and that I should ready some tissues.

I was afraid the game would be overhyped. While playing, I kept waiting for [i]that[/i] moment when everything would click, and I’d be a crying mess.

The game is different from what I expected. The sadness is subtle – not the in-your-face sadness and heartbreak I thought I’d get. 

I adore that “subtle” quality of To the Moon, but I know it’s also one of the reasons why this game isn’t for everyone. 

This game is perfect if you want:
[list]
[*]A story-driven game. The experience is more like watching a movie instead of playing a game.
[*]Something emotional and thought-provoking.
[*]Endearing characters and interesting dialogues. I love the touch of humor in this game.
[*]Something quick. You can finish it in one sitting.
[/list]

This game isn’t for you if you want:
[list]
[*]A comprehensive gaming experience. You don’t get a lot of games and puzzles to solve. There were also a few times when the gaming aspect didn’t feel organic, as if the developers incorporated it into the scene just to give you something to do.
[*]A ton of adventures. The story is already laid out, so you can’t explore as much as you’d like. Plus, the area you can walk around in is limited. 
[*]Something you can play several times.
[/list]

Overall, I [b]highly recommend[/b] this game to everyone.

131176255.review:
I've never played a story driven game before, but this came highly recommended. The story is beautifully moving, as promised, and I enjoyed it a lot. So many people describe it as a love story, but there’s more to it than that - at heart, it’s a story about grief, about identity, about the ties that bind us. 

Soundtrack is fitting, but the gameplay is a bit ad hoc (as some mystery games can be) and also repetitive (a few maze games interspersed with many iterations of the same puzzle game). The controls were frustratingly imprecise at times, but I chalk that up to its age. I may have enjoyed the story on its own more than as part of a game, though at times I did feel more involved than if I'd just been a passive consumer. Overall, well worth the time spent, even though it's old. I'm excited to play the sequels.

131120351.review:
- STORY : 10/10
I very much enjoyed the story of this game, it was very unpredictable which is exactly what i like, very rich and detailed, creative, emotional, simply amazing.

- VISUALS : 9/10
Beautiful and colorful, original assets, nice aesthetics, for a pixel art for sure is a 10, but in general I would give it a 9 to be fair towards some better art styles.

- SOUNDTRACK : 9/10
Very pleasant to the ear, relaxing, matches the story, emotional, very beautiful, I just wish there was more melodies it felt like there is only 3 repeating over and over.

- PRICE : 7/10
The original price is for sure a little too high for this type of game, but sale price is more than amazing, I received it for free as a gift from my friend so it was for sure worth it.

- LENGTH : 10/10
It took me something less than 5 hours to complete the game, which makes it a decent length for a short game, personally I enjoy short length games, so it is awesome.

- DIFFICULTY : 2/10
Very easy game to play, but there was couple difficult moments that don't really require any certain skill but it does take some time to understand what are you supposed to do.

- ACHIEVEMENTS : 1/10
I wish there was more than one ( very easy to get ) achievement in the game, because they make any game more enjoyable since I get some kind of satisfaction from completing them.

- STEAM BADGE : 10/10
It is for sure worth to get trading cards and the badge of any level for this game, since it is very aesthetic and looks good on your steam profile. 

- BAD SIDES : 
This game doesn't really have any bad sides except one thing which is inability of changing key binds, in my case I don't have arrow keys on my main keyboard, so I had to use another keyboard.

130691307.review:
Whenever I'd see games with that sort of design, I'd automatically assume that it was an RPG. And what's wrong about it? I mean, the engine that it was used to create it was pretty much developed for that kind of purpose. Nonetheless, the positive reviews have certainly drawn my attention and I decided to give it a go

So you take the role of two scientists who were hired to go through the thoughts of a dying man, with the objective of making his last wish to come true, through an artificial procedure. Throughout the way you get to learn more about his memories, thoughts and feelings. Even though there's not really any time limit, you still feel the urge and the pressure of rushing things as fast as possible, considering the patient's condition. There're also a few humorous interactions between the scientists which help to break the mood every now and then

Despite the RPG interface, we're talking about an adventure sort of game, where the main focus is simply the story, rather than playability. It sure does deliver on what it promises, combined with a fantastic soundtrack and despite simple, beautiful graphics. It also comes with a single achievement to be unlocked, which certainly helps to prevent backtracking

Overall, it's not really an extensive experience, but it's definitely a worthy one. I bought it for a really nice price and I surely recommend it to anyone who's interested in the adventure genre

与其称之为游戏，我更倾向于称其为一部沉浸式的电影。这是一款可以完全抛开游戏性，仅聚焦于剧情的游戏。它用恰到好处的互动和指引，将这个故事慢慢的呈现在了玩家面前。伴随让人潸然泪下的音乐，当一块块拼图逐形成轮廓时，我由衷地感到震撼和感动。

这故事也让我想起了命运石之门，在过去和未来之间疲于奔命，只为了实现一个遥远的执念，哪只是在记忆里。

世间最可怕的就是执念，它能以不可思议的力量推动人去做任何疯狂的事情。

结局是差强人意的。在两位博士帮助下，Johnny最终以一种扭曲的方式”实现“了自己的执念。即使这并不是真实发生的，但对于一个弥留之际的老人，这是对他而言最好的，也是他想要的。更让我心碎的是可怜的River。世上最爱她的人竟然忘了那些最美好的相遇和约定，而自闭症让她无法用言语与自己的爱人交流。她想尽了办法用尽了一切努力希望唤醒那个完整的Johnny，但终究还是抱着遗憾先行一步去了月球。他们相遇，相爱，以及那些天真却坚定的承诺，这些记忆在那丑丑的鸭嘴兽玩具，时钟的滴答声，残破的灯塔的见证下串联了他们毫无保留地相爱的一生，也像一把把尖刀狠狠扎在我心里...撕心裂肺的痛。

只因我知道毫无保留的爱一个人是什么滋味，更知道残缺不全的爱有多折磨。

他以为他用了一生去包容她，却不知道是她穷尽了一生去帮助他想起来他是谁。她的病让她无表达自己，折无数个兔子，剪去长发希望能让Johnny想起小时候短发的自己，把那个鸭嘴兽玩偶保留一辈子，甚至不惜放弃自己的生命，换来这座每天都能从窗户看到Annya的房子，盼着这座灯塔能让自己的爱人想起当年星空下的约定...

[spoiler]“我会得到...幸福。”[/spoiler]


然而现实就是这样，记忆不能也不应该被改变，因为人生本就该如此。没有人希望自己经历各种不幸，遗憾，悲伤，失去，但这些都是不可避免的，也是它们组成了活生生的人。如人生没有悲剧，那幸福将一文不值。尽管诸多不幸，他们至少都经历了彼此相爱的一生，已是羡煞旁人。

有笑有泪的神作，我会向所有认真对待爱情的人推荐这个游戏。

[spoiler]“那如果你忘记了……或者走丢了呢？”
“那么，我们总会在月亮上相见的，傻瓜！……就在小兔子的肚子那里！”[/spoiler]

130323839.review:
I didn't really know what to expect going in; I'd just seen this game on a list of "cozy steam games" and liked the art style and blurb, so when I saw the sale price I snatched it up. Just finished after two sessions. Just finished after two sessions. My take:

When it says story-driven, think "visual novel". You walk around and interact with people and objects, and in Act 1 (the longest act) there are several incremental simple mini-puzzles to solve. In Act 3 there's also a nifty little 'run & gun' style segment, but other than this, the game is basically reading. I wasn't into it at first, as much as I enjoy story, but I think that was cause I wasn't totally enamored with the pacing in Act 1...but when it was time for 2, man I was enthralled. All the set up was worth it, and that's all I'll say.

There was some spotlighting of neurodivergent characters which was pretty neat (and for a game over a decade old, pretty ahead of the game). I suspect someone in or related to development is in the camp given how non-existent these kinds of things are even in today's media. I mostly liked how the characters each had fairly distinctively written personalities; it helped animate the streams of text and made things feel a bit more alive.

My main gripe was also with the writing; when we catch up with the child versions of certain characters, they use some vocabulary that is absolutely unnatural for kids, and I'd been so immersed up to that point it felt [i]really[/i] jarring. It was if they were still young adults, and it was just...weird. Pretty inconsequential overall, but in a game that's all about dialogue and emotions, it hit disproportionately hard.

The other issue for me was that the game doesn't seem to support controller play. Why? This is basically a SuperNES game! It would've been much more physically comfortable for me to play with a controller than hunched over my trackpad/keyboard, just moving up right left down and interacting with things with spacebar or clicks.

If this is really your kinda game, I'd say buy it no question. If you're on the fence, I'd say the sale price is definitely worth it; as I said I'm not a huge point-and-click type, but I really enjoyed my time with this one.

130112761.review:
Este es un juego aparentemente muy sencillo, tanto en jugabilidad como en sus apartados técnicos, pero es de las experiencias más bonitas que he vivido con un videojuego en mucho tiempo. Su punto más fuerte es la historia, está contada a la perfección y te va llevando de la mano durante 4 horas en las que, la sensación de que hay algo por descubrir que te llenará el corazón de una manera que no imaginas, se va incrementando según llegas a la parte final (y menudo final). 

Lo tiene todo, es una historia que vamos descubriendo a la par que los dos protagonistas (aunque más que protagonistas son los 2 personajes que manejamos, los protagonistas reales son otros), cargada de momentos divertidos, tensos y sobretodo, bonitos. Jugablemente no tiene ninguna dificultad, consiste en avanzar junto con algún puzle esporádico (hiper sencillo), pero no necesita más, la historia, la música, hasta el apartado visual te tiene tan atrapado que la jugabilidad es lo de menos. Es un juego que vale totalmente la pena, hacía mucho que no lloraba tanto. 10/10 👌

130102579.review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

130063169.review:
[h1][b]To The Moon-Los Sueños Si Se Cumplen:[/b][/h1]

[h1]Contexto:[/h1]

Es un videojuego desarrollado por Freebird Games, tipo pixel art, que se enfoca en nárranos una historia, mientras, movemos tomamos los controles de esta.

[h1]Historia:[/h1]

Su historia aparenta pura felicidad, pero conforme pasamos las habitaciones y escenarios nos daremos cuenta de algo peculiar pues la doctora Eva descubrió a temprano momento lo que sucedía con nuestro protagonista, cada memento nos cuenta una pieza del pasado de nuestro cliente para buscar la pista de lo que necesitamos y cumplir con nuestro trabajo.

[h1]Destacado:[/h1]

Su banda sonora y personajes, lo simple que se mantiene todo mientras disfrutamos de sus paisajes, permite que no nos desviemos del caso que estamos atendiendo, adoro el cómo se lleva la Dra. Eva Rosalene y el Dr. Neil Watts, hacen que tengamos un alivio cómico y recuperarnos de lo que vamos viviendo. 

[h1]Puntos negativos:[/h1]

Quizá lo corto que es y que no podemos correr entonces el trayecto tiende a ser algo lento  en pocas ocasiones.

[h1]Resumen:[/h1]

Este juego me enseño que tarde o temprano ese sueño que tanto adoramos cumplir si será posible, en el único lugar donde tenemos control, nuestros sueños, las personas que conocemos y nos rodean hacen posible esto también, aprender a elegir es vital, me encanto cada parte del juego, no me esperaba la verdad y el final también me dejo con una lagrima de felicidad por como paso todo.

[h1][u]Mi Puntuación Es De: 9/10:[/u][/h1]

129972212.review: As someone with high functioning autism, I like how neurodivergence is handled in the story. Everything is well written, there is the odd joke or two that feel a bit out of place, but otherwise it was all amazing. The soundtrack is incredible and knows when to be quiet and when to be there. and my god that ending, this game is under priced for that ending alone. i haven't played the other games by the studio yet, but after playing this i am going to buy all of them. One important thing about it though, Don't buy it if you want good game play, that is not the focus of to the moon. The game play is alright, don't get me wrong, but all of it is about forwarding the amazing story rather than being in of itself entertaining. The puzzles mean you need to learn about the characters in order to progress, but none of them are particularly difficult, which i think is good for the story it is trying to tell. The story carries the game all the way through, and i think it more than makes up for the simple game play. 10/10.

129836870.review:
Its a charming little game that's probably worth the time needed to play it.

I like the core idea here and, while the game doesn't go into all that much depth about its ideas, I can look past that given its brevity. There's only so much you can do in the span of a few hours so just posing the questions rather than trying to answer them is good enough for me.

The story itself is simple, but still enjoyable. I cant say it had the same emotional impact on me that it did for many of those hailing it as a masterpiece, but I still think it had a strong enough emotional core to justify the few hours I spent with it.

The biggest gripe I have here is with the playable characters and their annoying sense of humor. To put it mildly, this definitely feels like a game written by people immersed in early 2010s internet memes. I really don't enjoy that kind of humor so its presence annoyed me to no end, but that might not be as big of an issue for others.

Probably worth a shot overall. Worst case scenario is that you're down $5 and a few hours of your time.

129577683.review:
To the moon is story first and a game second. 

Pros: 
-an touching story that may make you cry.
 -It's short (4h)
-It can be pretty funny.
-The score is eargasmic. Such a small game has no right to know how to make such a stunningly beautiful ost.


Cons: 
-You sometimes move at the pace of a slug and some areas are full of nothing, which means that if you skipped the item or person you needed to click on, you'll search for too long before coming back to where you needed to be.
- I had to use google multiple times to figure out what to do/where to go.
- I had to google the story afterwards to make sure I understood it, because there are some obvious plotholes ( [spoiler] like for example, why did John not go back to the festival to meet River again in the memory version where his brother survives?[/spoiler] )
- About River, the whole  [spoiler] revelation that she has Asperger's annoyed me. It might be a relic of this game's age, but you don't talk about someone being autistic behind doors like it's an incurable disease. It gave me *gasp! she's infertile* type of vibes. [/spoiler]
- The two scientists are very one-dimensional. It's the silly-bordering-stupid character and the smartass-serious character duo.

 It's a shame to have to say this, but this game isn't worth its normal price. I could have enjoyed the story so much, and as a tear-jerker enjoyer, reading the comments I expected to at least be fulfilled on that side. Sadly, I was constantly distracted by annoying gameplay and incoherent bits that pulled me out with a "wait... what?" It breaks my heart to give this a negative review because you can feel the passion and the love the devs had for this game. Who knows though, this game might be perfect for you. I thought it would be perfect for me but it wasn't.

I honestly think I would have loved this so much more as a novel. You might want to wait for a sale or watch a let's play first.

129201272.review:
Little can be said about this game that has not been said before but it deserves every word. 

If you're looking for a epic, hyper-realistic adventure with a lot of branching, it might not be the choice for you. But everyone hoping to delve into an immersive, evocative experience that tugs on their heartstrings should give [i] To The Moon [/i] a chance.

The two doctors create a pair of lovable protagonists and their dynamic adds a truly immaculate color to the plot. Silly banter contrasts with the more serious themes of the game. [i] To The Moon [/i] makes you laugh at the little jokes and then brings tears to your eyes with wonderings about loss, loneliness, and yearning to be loved and understood. 

The plot is accompanied by beautiful piano instrumental that adds a layer of magical warmth. Kan Gao's soundtracks acts both as an element of the story but also its background and does both jobs spectacularly well. Changes in the mood are highlighed by the tempo picking up or melting into melancholy.

Without spoiling the events of the game, as I believe they need to be experienced first-hand, I wholeheartedly recommend everyone to give John and River's story a chance. Fly towards the moon, fellow players~

129200088.review:
"The ending isn't any more important than any of the moments leading to it."

I'm not sure how to review this game because I've loved it for so long. It's the kind of game that each time I play it at different points of my life, there's something new I notice, new pieces I pick up and carry as I grow up. I've played it for at least the fourth time yesterday. I still cried a little.

If I were to describe the To the Moon series, it would be that they're very, very human stories about life and all the little things that make it worthwhile. It's bittersweet and tragic and messy at times, but amidst all of it are moments of hope and happiness and laughter and love, a whole lot of love.

To the Moon has a gift of storytelling that I haven't quite seen before. It has a beautiful soundtrack weaved along with the narrative, lovable and fun yet realistically flawed characters that I've grown to care so much about, and an emotional roller-coaster of a story that asks important questions and makes you take a step back and think.

If you're looking for a gem of a story you'll carry with you for years to come, please please play it. Let it take you on a ride, and don't forget to enjoy the scenery. To the Moon is my treasure, and I'll recommend it to everyone a thousand times.

P.S. I'd sell my soul to see this beautiful masterpiece of a game as a movie.

It is clear to me that a lot of time, effort, and care went into this game, and I do respect it for the work that it is. The soundtrack is great, and generally I was engaged enough with the game to play it to completion. 

That being said, I would not recommend this game to others. The plot is so weird and haphazard from the nonsensical time travel premise, to the bizarre and (personally) unsatisfying ending we're left with. This is a shame considering that there were some excellently written characters in the game who I feel were given clumsy character arcs by the end.

I wouldn't blame anyone for finding enjoyment out of this game, and I wouldn't bother writing this review if the game was free. But in my opinion, the plot I was presented with was incredibly lazy and frustrating to play through, to the point where I would suggest not going into the game at all if you're primarily interested in the story.

129160371.review:
[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

TLDR: A walking simulator that guides you on a cruise around an existential horror if you actually pay attention. 

Oh boy. This one is a lot to unpack. Its odd review time again, because this is… this is something. So let’s dive into it. 
Framed as a romantic and heart-warming short story, To The Moon is a pixel walking simulator interjected with a tile flipping mini-game that adds literally no value, and a couple of other poorly controlled minigames that just aren’t very interesting or fun. You play as a pair of doctors for an end of life service that go into dying people’s brains and alter their memories, so that they achieve a single dream they had throughout life. 
The idea, the potential, the protagonist doctors, and the way the story is told and unpacked are all so well done that they make the experience quite pleasant… but there is something deeply wrong with the story in and of itself that I will get to.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Deep characters that are well thought out, have their own motivations, unique personalities and relationships, and stay true to their world views. 
[*] Emotive story that is well told, with fitting music, and decent pixel art to go along with it. It made my cold dead orbs glisten once, brought a sad smile to my face, and made me laugh my brittle, dusty, laugh out loud at least once.
[*] The potential for this to become an *actual game* is huge. There were clearly plans for expansion throughout and I guess it was cut down to meet what was possible. I hope someday they’re met.  
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] The mini game is pointless. It plays out like it might do something and ultimately doesn’t. There is no consequence for taking 100 turns if you want, nor 1000. Nothing changes or is added.
[*] I felt like the game promised the moon (hurhurhur), teasing me with mysteries to unpick, paths to follow, and a time based mechanic that would only allow me a few actions per session so everything would count. 

It delivered a spam click and move around using poor controls mixed with minigames that also use poor controls. Were the story not so powerful this would be a major problem. 
[*] The lack of agency. 
This expansion deals with this in detail, it unpicks the ending of the game as well as character develoments, so be warned. 
[spoiler]Firstly, let’s look at the ending. We get no say in whether or not River should be erased in her current form. This is problematic in the sense that I agreed with Neil, not Eva.
Secondly, let’s look at what that eraser [i]means[/i]. They completely erased his life to allow him to build a delusion. It was to fulfil a last wish, yes, but does that make it morale? Was it even his actual wish? What if they were petty or vindictive people? Could anyone have known what they really did? What happens with the data of the constructed person? Is the Johnny that’s a read only program, really read only? What does it mean to be sapient? Is that facet just a program? Or is it real? Could it tell? If the program is a construct using brain base data to create a reality around itself to make a life, what separates it from a biologically constructed person? The morale implications are quite vast.
Finally. Let’s talk about River. The beauty lost in this is more tragic than anything else. [i]River knew. [b]She. KNEW.[/b][/i] Through their entire lives, she knew who he was. Exactly who he was. But he didn’t. We’ll never know if she knew he was a twin that lost one, or if she accepted the Joey/Johnny grandma link. We’ll never know if she worked that out, or pulled together [i]why he’d forgotten her[/i]. But she spent years building a constellation of rabbits to try and bring him home to her. To show him that she remembered the first times, that it was more than just teenage angst. She chose a spot with its own fucking light house for Christ’s sake, trying desperately to signal to him, to remind him of who he was. And she kept the platypus for what? 60 years? Eva missed the point. And destroyed it all because of wording. No delusion could have ever been as powerful, or meaningful, as John remembering, understanding, and appreciating the beauty of what River tried to give him, in her own way. Neil knew this, and understood what “I want to go to the moon” really meant. Robbing us of the chance to take him to the moon he wanted deep down was an absolute travesty, and swaps the story from being a touching and sombrely beautiful tale of missed opportunities and missing connection into an existential horror where the person who loves you most and is desperately trying to bring you back to yourself is erased, their efforts ground to dust and then thrown in your face as a façade of merriment so you can die without the guilt of not understanding them [i]when you could have changed it so that you did in the first place[/i] 
[/spoiler][/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]

 [list][*] Remove the minigames that add absolutely nothing to the game. 
[*] Expand on the mysteries and puzzle solving stuff. There’s an entire house to explore in the present, and an entire life to explore the history of, it would have been a lot of fun if you could jump in and out, forward and back, and use the things around the house and his memories to try and unlock the passages to the next sections by filling in his memories with the data around them… possibly making mistakes along the way, changing the outcome of the story. 
[*] Provide multiple endings, based on spoiled changes. 
[/list]

[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

The thing is, this is well worth buying and playing. It only cost a couple of quid while on off, and even though it only took me 5 hours, including stopping for dinner, putting the kids to bed, and while chatting with folks through the power of the internet (though the steam overlay didn’t work, which I suppose should be a con). In terms of raw value, this gives way more weight than it costs for the feels alone.
But the lack of agency, the spoilerd issues, and the teased potential…  
If you can appreciate the beauty in tragedy, then this is for you. If you don’t really think philosophically, and take it at face value, it’s absolutely for you. But if you think deeply, consider morale implications, outright dislike walking simulators, or are concerned about having an impact within a story, it isn’t.

128839008.review:
[h1] Tldr; Mediocre controls slapped on an otherwise great story with dull protagonists who won't shut up. [/h1] 

I was baited by the "overwhelmingly positive" reviews on Steam and it needs to be acknowledged that the story is emotional and deserves all the praise. But that's about the only positive this game has. Despite being a story-driven game, it's not justified if the game play is clunky and if the protagonists (that have 80% of dialogue) keep interrupting an otherwise smooth immersion into a heart-gripping tale. 

The puzzles are repetitive and get monotonous rather quickly as little is to be achieved from tile-inverting minigames. The pixel graphics may be good to look at, but with invisible barriers everywhere, it's a dumb click-fest just to get your character to move where he/she needs to so the story can progress. 

The protagonists are apathetic and constantly taking a jibe at the journey of the man whose dream they are supposed to be fulfilling which defeats the whole purpose of the story. The music is decent but the negatives of this game outweigh the positives which makes it impossible to recommend that someone pay money for this lackluster excuse of a video game. If you want to buy, make sure you pick it up during a sale, full price is undeserved. 

I may be in the minority in not recommending this game; I have no hesitation in paying for a 5-hour game focusing on a good story but if I had to drag myself just to get to the end and if the game itself feels like a chore, the payoff is not worth anyone's money or time no matter how good the story is.

Edit: Typos fixed.

128462658.review:
I should start by mentioning that I first heard about this game through a YouTuber named "TheMysteriousMrEnter." He's used music from this game in his videos and credited the songs from the OST. I looked up the game itself, and I initially thought this was going to be an homage to JRPG's from the Super Nintendo and Sega Genesis era, like Undertale. The game itself makes a small joke about that, pretending to start up a turn-based battle, but then they just move forward.

I will say, first and foremost, that I enjoy the narrative and presentation. The graphics, while simple, use a lot of muted colors and a low resolution to create a realistic atmosphere; the music is beautiful, especially the main theme, "Everything's Alright."

The premise is an interesting idea, where two scientists, Eva Rosalene and Neil Watts, work together to alter a dying man's memories, to fulfill his wish to travel to the moon. As the game goes on, you see what sparked this motive, and the life he and his family had over the years. There's also several unexpected turns that leave you guessing how this man dealt with tragedies and grief that occurred in his life, and what the scientists will do to achieve their mission. I was about to HATE the ending when the female scientist went off by herself to alter the man's memories in a certain way, because it meant the man would completely forget about a huge chuck of his life, one that he should be able to remember; but then I see how she replaced his memories, and the payoff at the end, as well as her actions, felt justified.

So what's my problem here? The gameplay, or lack thereof. As I mentioned, this is not an RPG like I was expecting; it's an adventure game where you solve puzzles and use the man's memories to, in a sense, travel through time. You can't go all the way back to his earliest memories in one "memory hop", you have to perform numerous backwards hops over the course of the man's life. You do this by finding a "memento", a concrete object from the man's memories, which have to be activated using 5 "memory links", other objects and small details in the background found by combing over a contained environment. When you take the memory links to the memento and activate it, you solve a simple puzzle, which is flipping all the tiles to form a picture of the memento. You have to do this process at least 7 or 8 times, while watching the story play out; it gets just as repetitive, and sometimes confusing, as finding a certain number of magical glowey things in a 3D platformer to unlock the next stage. Once you've done this process enough times, you have to link the mementos together in a chain so the scientists can go back to the man's earliest memory, alter it, and set a butterfly effect into motion, thus fulfilling his wish.

But that's just Act 1! The second act of the game involve the scientists finding alternative methods to go all the way back to the man's earliest memory, which they can't immediately access; the third act of the game is watching the earliest memory, followed by a disjointed climax where Dr. Watts has to chase down Dr. Rosalene who goes off on her own to alter the man's memories, without explaining the plan to him. Throughout all of this, there's 5 or 6 detours that the scientists have to take to solve problems, and the solutions they come up with are sometimes nonsensical. 

Again, I like the narrative of this game, but that's just it: this story doesn't work as a video game! The gameplay, while interactive, is so minimal, that a single playthrough just becomes a tour through set pieces, automatically moving forward in a straight line at a certain pace. The most freedom you get is talking to NPC's and looking at certain objects in the contained environments. This should've been a graphic novel or an animated movie, because it feels disjointed and bogged down as an interactive medium.

Even the two free "minisodes" are just really short epilogues where you're wandering back and forth through the building where the scientists work.

Speaking of them, another problem I have is the two scientists as characters. Dr. Rosaline and Dr. Watts spend the WHOLE GAME constantly bickering and trying to one-up each other over the course of their mission. It's fine if they're not best of friends, or they disagree on how to go about the mission, but they don't even act professional or civil with each other; it's just mindless fighting and word games between these two. They obviously need to be there as protagonists, and they shouldn't just be blank slates, but when I follow a pair of grown adults acting like children fighting on the playground, and I have to watch the story unfold from their perspective, it ends up bringing down what's otherwise a beautiful story about seeing a dying man's dreams come true. Imagine going to a large, elaborate wedding, and you have to sit next to your two friends who spend the whole ceremony yelling at each other in the back of the venue; that's my metaphor for the scientists in this game.

So I unfortunately can't recommend this game. Watch a "Let's Play" on YouTube to experience the story, and then buy the soundtrack on the developers' Band Camp page, instead. You'll actually get more out of it that way.

128149706.review:
After nearly 5 hours I finally finished this game. I don't know how to put a label on this game: a love story, an adventure, a memory lane, or ultimately just a dream, but a very beautiful beautiful dream? 

Act 1 is quite introductory, providing the general background info. 
Act 2 is where things getting more and more interactive and intense. I started to lose my self-awareness and slowly found my temporary replacement with the protagonist (i.e., John). I cheered for "our" bravery to talk to River, I smiled at "our" wedding, and I secretly paid attention to River as well, especially when she walked, her hair flipped from side to side. 
Act 3 is the big finale, where everything was unraveled and reached to conclusion. I finally understand all the reasons behind John's wishes. Because, "then we can always regroup on the moon, silly". As John's heart rate slowly dropped, and finally ended up with a "beep-", I was happy to see that they were holding hands and had each other company. 

John was very patient just for this moment. Thankfully, he had it.

I have cried multiple times throughout the game, all of which were good cries, hard cries, and loud cries. I guess fate would always lead me back to the loved ones, no matter how many times they get lost. I guess River is not a lighthouse after all, because she was, till the very end of her day, remembered by John, and her light always shined brightly on John.

I won't spoil any more than that, but I remember bawling my eyes out at the credits and I honestly never do that for a game or a film at all, not even Infinity War/ Endgame. 

If you just want to feel dead inside for a few days absolutely give this a go

I was looking at Steam sales with my boyfriend, and I see this game on his wish list. Not knowing the game, I asked him what kind of game it is, and he was so PUZZLED that I had [i]"never heard of this masterpiece"[/i] that I had to stop him because he wanted to buy the game for me.
I ended up buying it, and it was worth it. [b]A lot.[/b]
[h1]This game is a rollercoaster of emotions.[/h1]
The story is about this dying old man who wishes to go to the moon, and it is you who will try to make it happen, playing as Eva and Neil.
I loved every moment of this game, from the beginning to the ending of the story, the music, the plot twists, and the characters. Everything was made for you to love it, so you can slowly die inside (of fun, ofc!).
The thing that I liked the most are the two protagonists, the usual comic duo who are like fire and water. (expect [b]EVERYTHING[/b] from them).
The only flaw is that the game is a bit old, so there is a lot of lag, especially in the dialogues (most of the time they scroll very slowly; I even accidentally skipped some sentences because the dialogue animation was too slow).

125847084.review: I've had this game in my library for ages, but everyone seemed so emotional about it that I was hesitant to play it because I didn't knew how would it affect me. Now that I've finally played it, including the two minisodes, I have to say that it's been really worth it, and I should have played it sooner because I was missing out something really special. Maybe some aspects of the game are not up to snuff (mainly the control; I couldn't get it to work with the XBOX controller, even if it's suppossed to work with this game, and the keyboard+mouse setting is kind of faulty), and maybe there isn't really much gameplay involved, just light point and click stuff to keep the story going and some easy puzzles in the middle, but it's the fantastic storytelling that kept me on my seat. There are quite a few memorable moments (some tender, some sad, and some funny) and fantastic characters that you get to care for in the end. To The Moon is truly a gem, and something every gamer should experience on its own.

125510682.review:
My husband insisted I play the game, since he is in love with it.
I was quite skeptical at first:
* the controls felt off and there is no way to change them
* you constantly get stuck on the landscape objects
* the cursor is all over the place and clicking to interact does not always work

Many comments complain about the 2 main characters' constant bickering, I however, liked it very much.
Storywise, I rolled my eyes a couple of times at how vague River was - I got this "not the same as everyone else" mysterious vibe pushed really hard, like some sort of Twilight main characters (this was later explained by her condition though).

Mild spoilers ahead:
[spoiler] As the story unfolded the pieces came together and the whole thing turned out to be heart-breaking. I did cry and then cried again afterwards. Nevertheless, there is this doubt in my heart - the complete overhaul of John's memory feels like a betrayal. Like his years with real River were thrown way, even if he got some memories back in the end. He essentially became a different person and his new River was a different person as well.

This also makes me think about the scene at the doctor's office, where John declined to read the book about River's condition. Could it be that his words to Nicolas were true? Did he just like himself around River, but never really cared to understand her? That's why he was ready to overwrite the memories of real River just to be happy with a more convenient version? [/spoiler]

The story leaves us with many moral/philosophical questions, and this is a sign of a good story I believe.
I am glad I played the game.

125453424.review: A short game about a company that grants the final wish of loved ones just before they pass away, To the Moon, is about how the company works. In a short amount of time, you not only learn some profound and unexpected things about the character who is dying, but you also learn about the people who are attempting to assist him through his final moments and grant the dying wish that he has expressed. This game also includes two additional, smaller games! The mini-games will make more sense if you play the main game first. It is primarily a text adventure, but some involve point-and-click gameplay. :)

125271464.review:
This game arguably changed my life in a significant and profoundly positive way, which I believe on its own should speak volumes as to its quality. 


However, I love this game enough that I want to make an in-depth review for it. In this review I will be breaking down the good, the great and the rest. Despite my praise, I believe this game is not necessarily for everyone, and I will explain why later in this review.


- The Good -

I want to start with the basics. This game’s engine is a double-edged sword. For now, I will cover its merit. The engine works excellently for what this game requires of it. RPG Maker is a fantastic engine for basic game mechanics and efficient storytelling. This game just so happens to have extremely barebones game mechanics and a whole lot of story to tell in its short playtime. This game could arguably be viewed as a playable movie to an extent. What few mechanics there are boil down to movement, item collection and some small gimmicks. These gimmicks are utilised to great effect, giving the game a unique identity, despite limitation. These mechanics exist solely to serve the purposes of the story, and that is perfectly fine.

The RPG Maker engine gives the game a timelessness that allows it to remain intentionally retro in style, excusing its bare mechanics in exchange for them being utilised for storytelling. This means that despite the game being quite old, the engine’s simplicity makes it feel as though it could have been released last year.

The pacing in this game, on account of its minimalistic approach to gameplay, revolves around its story. While this game’s story is incredible, its pacing could arguable be seen as a little slow in some places, yet remains engaging enough throughout to be classed as “good”.


- The Great –

Here’s the elephant in the room. The story. This game’s story is what everyone should be here for. The aforementioned minimalistic game mechanics only serve to facilitate the efficient delivery of this brilliant story. While the pacing isn’t perfect, the concepts, character, dialogue and overall execution of its themes more than make up for it. You will laugh, you may even cry, but what’s most important is that this game will most certainly make you feel SOME way, which is sadly somewhat of a rarity in the age of the Battle Pass.

Character development in this game is pulled off to great effect, which is done in spite of its unconventional temporal structure. I won’t go any further on this in the interest of avoiding spoilers. Characters are built throughout this story, which are expanded further in the equally brilliant sequels. You will come to love these characters with time. They are given imperfections, goals and habits which make them relatable and enjoyable to experience. You will leave the presence of these characters wanting more. Some of them are the kind of characters you would be thrilled to watch buying their groceries.

This game takes a simple, yet engaging premise and expands it to the point at which it becomes something of a masterclass in emotive storytelling. This premise is not necessarily entirely unique, yet is spun in a unique enough way to push the story and its characters into positions in which they become the player’s entire focus during gameplay. This game is beautiful enough that it has changed my perspective on life and death itself and helped me feel a sense of peace. I cannot say exactly how it did this without spoiling the story.

The music is incredible. Every single track will stick with you, with some of the signature tracks bringing tears to your eyes every time you hear them after the game is over. This is the kind of soundtrack to make you feel nostalgic over a game you just finished playing 10 minutes ago. Brilliant and emotionally composed - this soundtrack is a smash hit.


- The Rest –

I spoke of the game’s engine being a double-edged sword. This is where I describe the other edge. While the basic engine makes for great storytelling, its limitations mean this game might not be what everyone is looking for. Some people simply are not interested in a story-centric gaming experience, as they would rather just watch a movie and avoid having to walk through it themselves. This game is not for those people. If you are looking for intricate gameplay and engaging mechanics in a video game, then this is not for you.

On top of this, the RPG Maker engine has a very iconic look to it that not everyone may find appealing. Some people simply think the game looks ugly, and that is fine since it’s a subjective thing. However, I would still recommend this game to those people despite that. The game’s story is brilliant enough to outweigh any visual grime viewers may feel is off-putting.


TL;DR – If you have even the slightest bit of interest in a good and engaging story, and can spare enough to pay for this game’s small price, then I believe there is no better use for your money on the market.
If you are ONLY interested in intricate and engaging game mechanics, then look elsewhere.


This game is a timeless classic. Giving it a 10/10 would not be enough.


Masterpiece/10

125063407.review:
Overall: 7.5/10 (with the caveat of having significant patience, since this is a RPG Maker game)
Time to complete story: 5 hrs (Med-to-fast play speed)

Story: 8/10
Characters: 7/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Art: 7/10
Audio: 7/10
UI: 6/10

Very interesting concept and story, held back by the slow movement speed (didn't find a sprint button), slow text progression, and slow cut scenes. I assume these are common annoyances with stories/games told through the RPG Maker engine, which I haven't played many of. But I believe that gameplay and story progression speed need to be weighted against the story impact. Hence, my overall score being dragged down more than others who seem to be focused on the latter. I didn't give it too much time, but I also couldn't seem to get my gamepad to do anything in the game. I felt the need to hop to my third-party software instead of Steam Input to map KBM to gamepad and start playing from my couch in any sort of decent time.

I'm glad my family member dropped out of watching around 3 hrs in, because while we can be patient for thorough world-building or storytelling (which this game somewhat did), we're also both fast readers bored by EVERYTHING being slow with this game engine. Now I can show them the last bits of impactful storytelling before jumping to the ending we've been painfully waiting and "playing" for. Honestly, the ending did (almost) move me to tears like many other people, and that was even with preparing and steeling myself after warnings by other reviews. The characters were a bit too casual and the jokes a bit weak for my taste, as well as the art and audio seeming average for this type of game, but the thorough look at the concept and this one man's life was impactful and well-executed.

Score comparison:
HLtB:        8.3/10 (1,501 votes)
Metacritic: 8.8/10 (1540)
Steam:      96% positive (48,099)

125029930.review:
I'm normally the kind of person that sticks to FPS games, VR, action, and horror. I generally avoid games that advertise themselves as "immersive art", or "emotionally driven", or "rich story". I'm not a fan of pixellated art, either. Somehow I ran into this game, not quite knowing what I was going to get myself into, and for some reason decided to give it a try.

I've shed some tears in some emotional moments in movies and TV shows, and I consider myself to be decently soft. I didn't just shed some tears in this game, I had to pause playing it to uncontrollably sob. Twice.

The mystery and buildup for the first ~2 hours is brilliant. Finding all these sorts of little clues, asking myself, "why this? What is the meaning?" Chekov's Gun was perfectly done here, as everything has a purpose and a part. It all comes together in the climax of the game, where every piece you've found finally clicks into place, and all of the 'why' questions are finally answered in perhaps one of the sweetest, heartfelt moments I have seen on a screen. And even after that... just wait. Be patient. There is still more goodness to come.

I don't care if this art style isn't for you, or if you only play games that involve weapons. If your heart doesn't melt and you don't cry at least a little bit, maybe it's a good time to see a licensed psychologist and get checked out.

125018193.review: Remarkable story-telling. In the first 30 minutes I kept wondering "Why am I playing this?!" – it's not that I don't mind games that are mostly just "narrative experiences", but RPG Maker games tend to be a bit janky and this one is no exception. But the characters and world draw you in so quickly that you forget all about that and just want to keep going to learn more. And before you know it you're sitting in front of your PC, crying, while the credits play.

124584815.review:
It's times like these where I wish Steam just had a 5 star rating system, or allowed you to rate neutrally at the very least. Because I don't hate this game, but I also don't love it either.

I was a bit oversold on this game. I think for its time it would have been brilliant, but nowadays it's a bit dated in its writing. There are a lot of antique references, some of which I'm pretty sure were old even at the time. The protagonists are inconsistent and have baffling moments where they act in such unlikable ways that I had to really hold on to like them, especially when the game's earnest and hopeful nature is frequently lampooned by their need to wisecrack. They conflict with eachother in an initially amusing way but it gets grating and even unnecessarily comes to a conflict by the end. There's a balance to be struck with that, and here it's too much for me. 

The gameplay is non-existent, the puzzles are just decorative and I didn't get why they were there if they had no bearing on the story, the ending or even just for score chasing. I frequently got stuck on parts of the scenery like flowers and rocks and bushes because they've littered every scene with these decorative pieces with collision. Traversing in a top down RPG style should be much more intuitive than it was here. Every time I got placed in an outdoor environment, I let out a sigh. In fact, it's games like this that have me raising a suspicious eyebrow, questioning if they deliberately added all the walking around to pad out the length of the game. It doesn't serve the experience effectively.

I'm someone that holds film to a higher regard than video games, so I have a distinctive preference between the two when it comes to certain things. For me, I need to feel my own presence in the game or have some kind of influence over the story in some shape or form, even if it's in the most minuscule way. That can be as simple as fourth wall breaks, or just some freedom to explore the environment around me. This game is aggressively linear and you have very little sway over what happens. And when the presentation is as lo-fi as this and yet requires just enough input from you to keep it moving forward, it feels like a concerted yet unnecessary effort to push the story forward and I found it hard to immerse. I didn't get the point of mashing interact on random sprites in the scene to try and unlock another memory point to progress the story. To this effect, it's very much a product of the time where Lets Plays were the preferred way to experience a game so you didn't have to do that kind of minimal interaction yourself.

Anyway, all that aside, I really did enjoy what this game tried to do. It's practically a Charlie Kaufman love letter and I dig the hell out of that. But it's bogged down by its dated engine, poor gameplay and questionable character direction. I wish I'd gotten to this one back in 2011 when it was a novelty. I know this game was one of the big champions of not only independent games as an industry, but also the whole 'Are video games an art form' debate. And while I wholeheartedly agree to that notion, this game is ironically not one I would point to for this. I would have enjoyed it more as a visual novel, a book, or even (In some alternative reality where something like this would secure a big enough budget) a movie like the ones it proudly wears on its sleeve as inspiration. But then at that point you could watch Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, or Synecdoche New York instead.

124208902.review:
I rarely leave reviews and almost never bad ones but, in this case, I really feel I have to address something. This game was a huge disappointment for me. I was very much looking forward to playing it, especially given the incredible reviews, but by the end I was just frustrated and let down.

Mild spoilers: The game gives a prominent spotlight to a character with autism (though the game never uses the actual term) and though it is incredible to see representation for people on the spectrum, it was (in my opinion) very poorly executed. Another character is somehow painted as being such a 'trooper' for sticking with them despite how 'difficult' they are due to their autism. The game insists on painting a very negative picture of what it is like 'dealing' with people who are on the spectrum and neglects to talk about the positives.

Heavy spoilers: the game even goes as far as to make the happy ending one where their life with the autistic character is entirely erased in favour of a constructed, false life with a dead relative.

When I read up on it, it didn't surprise me to learn that the creator donated to Autism Speaks which is, by many in the community, considered to be a harmful hate group that spreads dangerous notions about autism.

Really saddened to have to leave a review like this and I get that some people think the representation is actually handled well but for me, it very much missed the mark.

124128287.review:
[h1] To The Moon - Like Tears In Rain [/h1]

It's funny how every once in a while you run into a game that leaves such an impression on you, you're almost afraid to replay it. The memory of it is so perfect, after all, that you can't help but wonder if reliving it might spoil it in some way.

I'm still working up the courage to replay Morrowind. Meanwhile, here's another one that's pretty close to my heart.

[h2] What Would the Story of Your Life Look Like? [/h2]

The story follows doctors Eva Rosalene and Neil Watts, employees of Sigmund Corp. The company describes itself as a "life generation service" - they create and implant artificial memories in dying clients, making them believe they've lived a perfect life in which all their dreams came true.

Eva and Neil's latest assignment leads them to Johnny Wyles. Johnny is a widower, living with his caretaker and her two children in a cliffside manor overlooking an abandoned lighthouse. Johnny has one final wish - he wants to get to the moon. The only problem is, he doesn't know why.

This presents a unique challenge for our protagonists. Without knowing the root of Johnny's desire to go to the moon, any memories they craft risk being rejected by his dying mind.

This is the framework the entire game revolves around. Controlling Eva and Neil, your job is to relive Johnny's memories and discover why he wants what he wants. Only then can you reconstruct his life story and make his new memories convincing and satisfying.

To discuss the plot in any more detail would only amount to one huge spoiler. To the Moon is more of a narrative experience than a game, one you have to try for yourself to fully appreciate.

Suffice it to say that the story deals with difficult themes such as love, loss, otherness, and the ways we inflict and process trauma. The characters and situations are nuanced, and they leave room for interpretation without telling you how you should feel. And even though the writing sometimes leans on some pretty well-worn tropes, the sheer sincerity of the way it's presented makes it work for me.

[h2] Pretty Basic, But That's OK [/h2]

It's not an exaggeration to say that To the Moon barely has any gameplay. This is, of course, by design - the gameplay is simply there to service the unfolding story.

You control either Eva, Neil, or both, depending on the scene. You'll mostly be using the mouse, with the option of moving the characters using the arrow keys. The moment-to-moment feel bears a strong resemblance to old-school point-and-click adventures, while avoiding some of the frustrating features inherent to those games, such as illogical puzzles or pixel hunting.

In fact, there aren't really any puzzles to speak of. Each scene represents one of Johnny's memories that the main characters can witness and interact with. While doing this, your job is to find 5 thematically significant "objects" in each scene.

The "objects" in question can be actual objects, but also persons, situations, or even environments you move through. These will act as keys to unlock the sixth, final object, which gives you a brief minigame to solve before transporting you to the next scene.

The game was made in RPG Maker, and is thus rendered in a familiar pixel-art style. The art design makes good use of the limited graphics and creates a cozy and inviting environment to explore. The sound design is completely adequate, mixing fairly generic sound effects with a few well-crafted score tracks.

There are a few minor moans with the gameplay and graphics, though. Until about two-thirds into the game, pretty much every object you can interact with is one of the five keys you need to find to proceed. It is only much later in the game you get some non-essential objects or flavor dialogues. With this in mind, I can see some people wondering if this even had to be a game, as opposed to a visual novel.

Also, due to the limitations of the game engine, the display resolution is stuck at 640*480. The screen scrolls pretty fast, and the fairly strong color/VHS distortions in some memory scenes can cause a lot of eye strain.

[h2] Still Got It [/h2]

To the Moon is an indie game in the best sense of the word - a clear creative vision brought to life by a team on a limited budget. It knows exactly what it wants to be and delivers on it with aplomb.

It also has the dubious achievement of being the only game to ever make me cry, so there's that.

[b] TLDR: [/b] An indie narrative adventure about life, death, and everything in between.
[b] Pros: [/b] Excellent story and writing.
[b] Cons: [/b] Very limited gameplay and graphics.

[h3] Final Score: 8/10 [/h3]

124008991.review:
"Short steps, deep breaths, everything is alright"

This game is an emotional journey that will have most people crying and legitimately losing themselves in the story and characters. When I first met my husband he wanted me to play this game, I did and I loved it right away (one section of it even having me ugly crying and talking to the screen), it was the kind of game you could pick up and play in one sitting, but that would sit with you forever. I bonded with my husband over the main song in it, hoping it and the game had made him think of us, which years later I found out it did. At our wedding our first dance was to the main song in this game and I'd consider it to be our song. I think it'll especially hit close for people with mental illness of any kind, as I often feel misunderstood, but this game makes me feel seen. It makes the concept of love itself feel seen.
The only downside I'd say is the little puzzle parts of the game, I honestly don't think it needs them, to me it's a perfect story game with random pointless small bits of uninteresting gameplay that feel tacked on to make it feel more like a "game". To me though we're way beyond that in the gaming world and it's okay to just have an immersive universe that takes you into it without adding in gameplay elements. The game touches on perfection many times but then loses itself trying to find it's place in a Steam storepage, when really Steam is the one that should be begging to have it there.
If you're okay sobbing at the screen and yearning to hug a romantic partner then pick up this game for sure.

123941059.review:
This game is a very good idea and story concept, but trips over itself the whole way. My wife and I sat down and completed it in 2 evenings, and it was a marginally enjoyable (while emotional) experience. The thing that really got in the way of this being a great game was, unfortunatly, the petty and combative characters. Almost every conversation or interaction between any 2 characters was colored by spite. Especially the 2 protagonists you control throughout the game. They seem to hate each other, take every opportunity to cut each other down, and do not grow or develop noticeably throughout the story. The only characters that don't seem to have a terrible attitude toward other people are the characters that have almost no speaking role in the game. To have such petty and spiteful characters essentially narrating the deep emotional story of a dying man was jarring and distracting. I ended up hating the 2 'protagonists' (player characters), and only somewhat sympathized with the man on his death bed, more because of his circumstances than his character as a person. Additionally, the 'Grand Conclusion' that the game rewrites for this man in his memories (the point of the game) seems only to be superficially better than the man's actual life as a whole, leaving me to feel as though the end result is generally valueless. Though I could have accepted the ending if the characters that brought it about weren't just occasionally (or accidentally) compassionate.

I genuinely hope the writer of this game has known much kinder people than the ones in this story.

123739296.review:
To The Moon revolves around Dr. Wyatt and Dr. Rosaleane, scientists who live in a world where it's possible to recreate memories. This allows the scientists to give dying people a chance to live out their final request. This game is the first installment.

To The Moon tells the story of Johnny Wyles, an old man on his deathbed whose dying wish is to go to the moon. He can't remember why he desires to travel there, he's not sure why he's so passionately drawn to it but he finds deeply that he must. So it's up to the scientists to craft and decipher his true desire of why to help his dying wish come to fruition.

They have to traverse his memories, all of which are cheerfully happy, bittersweet and full of tragedy. 

Memories are messy and how we perceive them can develop how we carry ourselves. The game heavily revolves traversing Johnny's innermost thoughts and his most personal moments to implant the memory of him visiting the moon.

This game is beautiful. It promotes the provoking exploration of love, loss and desire. The game also covers various topics that touch the hearts of many, the very complications that make life ever so beautiful. Mental illness, death, heartbreak, tragedy, all covered in such a charming and captivating way.

The story is enchanting and the musical scores hold such a closeness to my heart that I can't help but find myself NOT to share the experience with others, I give this game to everyone I enjoy being around, I find it to be a piece of me now and I can't help but want to share these moments with others. It's such a lovely game.

Buying this game on the Freebird Games Website allows you to purchase the soundtrack, a purchase that a percentage of course goes to aiding various mental health charities. So if you feel a little charitable and find yourself wanting to enjoy a enrapturing story... buy this game. You won't regret it <3

Recordemos que esto es un videojuego en el cual la historia solo es un elemento más de todos los que lo conforman, y como videojuego es una interacción directa del jugador con lo que sucede en pantalla, debo decir que de juego no tiene casi nada, el puro pretexto de mover al personaje de aquí para allá (con unos controles horribles) para contarnos la historia, que honestamente conforme jugaba ya deseaba que se acabara, quería presenciar la historia si, pero el gameplay horrible me hacía querer terminar lo antes posible.

La música es bonita, con el detalle que es muy repetitiva, durante todo el juego reconocerás si acaso las mismas 2 o 3 canciones. Los "puzzles" que tiene son un chiste, son siempre los mismos y no tardas más que unos segundos en hacerlos, supongo yo que están para intentar sumarle algo de juego a lo poco o nulo que hay.

Si abres el menú verás cosas como objetos que has recolectado, algunas notas, la salud del paciente sobre quien gira la trama, si pones el mouse en la parte alta de la pantalla puedes ver el momento en la vida de tu paciente donde te encuentras dentro de sus recuerdos... con el detalle de que de todo lo que acabo de mencionar, nada es necesario para terminar el juego, bien podría no haber menú y no cambiaría nada, nunca requieres abrirlo para interactuar con absolutamente nada de lo que hay ahí, bien podría ser solo un menú para guardar y cargar la partida, eso si fuera un juego largo, porque para su corta duración ni siquiera es necesario guardar, salvo que se te vaya la luz en medio de una partida, para lo que algo mejor sería que el juego tuviera checkpoints y listo ya que además el juego es 100% lineal, bien se habrían podido ahorrar el menú.

Como recomendación ve un playthrough en youtube (uno sin comentarios, ya que los youtubers de ahora seguro que sobreactuan y te llenan de gritos el video con tal de que los vean), y no solo ahorras algo de dinero, si no que no te pierdes de absolutamente nada jugablemente hablando, eso sí te ahorras el coraje de tener controles horribles.

123527993.review:
There's a simple way to tell if this game is for you. Watch the trailer with the sound on, from the beginning and without skipping. If it becomes unbearably bittersweet at around 2:00-2:30, you feel your throat clamping up and your eyes watering, then yes, this game is for you. If not, then the story might not resonate with you; and the gameplay isn't exactly a reason to play this.

I never managed to watch the trailer in its entirety. This game is, in a sense, like a horror game; you're constantly anxious about getting hit with a rocket of industrial-grade feels. And when they come, they hit you hard. Now, I'm a rather sensitive person and crying in games isn't something that is [i]that[/i] unusual for me; I got my eyes wet at the end of Dear Esther, and during that moment in Mass Effect with the Geth and the... you know. Outer Wilds and OPUS: Echo of Starsong also got me emotional. Now, with that said...

I [i]ugly cried[/i] FOUR TIMES during this 3 hour game. And one more time in between sessions. It feels like this game was made by disassembling me to my very basic elements, carefully isolating the most vulnerable of them, and designing a formula that would trigger them all at once. This is of course very personal and there's no way to tell if this will hit you the same way, but that trailer test I mentioned before should be a good starting point.

No, I won't tell you what the game is about. The trailer says all you need to know. All I'm going to say is that the story is well paced and well written; there's foreshadowing, thematic consistency... but also some mood whiplash which I believe is intentional. One character is a gigantic dork that will make your eyes roll multiple times, but... in the end, it somehow makes sense. I think.

Oh, and the controls are freaking antediluvian. You can either point-and-click and watch your guys get stuck on walls, or walk... using arrow keys and the spacebar. I guess WSAD wasn't that well established in 2011. Would make more sense to play on a controller, but I couldn't get it to work.

To wrap things up... this is a game that will make you sad. The good kind of sad, but sad nonetheless. It touched me so hard, I'm getting a Pavlovian reaction to this game - listening to its music instantly brings me close to tears. It's embarrassing, actually. Do you want to feel this good kind of sadness? I'd say those tears are a nice shower for the soul. But I wouldn't blame you if you said there are plenty of other, more real things to cry about.

(PS. The minisodes aren't as good as the main game, but still decent)

121959141.review:
[h1] Emotional Story Telling At Its Best [/h1]

To The Moon is an amazing example of why video games are such a special medium to tell stories with. You play as two doctors, who are tasked with helping bring people's dying wishes to life, and in this case your patient is Johnny, and his wish is very simple. He want's to go to the moon. Throughout your 4 hour journey, you travel through his memories, watching him live through his life, and discover a tragic tale of love, loss, and tragedy. As you take this journey, you discover secrets and must come to a decision. Do you change the past so that you can give him the life that he wanted? How does this affect his life? How does this affect the people he loves? How does this affect the people around him? Is it even worth the risk? These are the questions you face in To The Moon, and it creates one of the best stories I've had the pleasure of playing through. 

[h2] Narrative [/h2]

The pacing in To The Moon is great. You never feel like the story is being dragged down by filler, and it's constantly moving along. While some games might rush certain aspects, not giving characters time to develop and become fleshed out, especially in a shorter game like this, To The Moon allows you to get to know each character, and become attached to them. The two doctors you play as have amazing chemistry, and are quite hilarious, something I wasn't expecting from a game as emotional as this one is. The game also knows when to be serious though, and show the human side of them as well. You see them struggle with choices, and question if what they're doing is ultimately the right thing to do. You will see Johnny throughout all stages of his life, from childhood to death, so you really get to know him as a person, as well as his friends and family. Its a gut wrenching story that is both painful, yet inspirational, and it gave me a feeling that's hard to describe. As emotional and sad as the story is, it didn't leave me feeling sad as I would have expected but gave me hope, and looking up, not down. It's a story you truly need to experience for yourself.

[h2] Presentation [/h2]

While graphically it might not have the latest and greatest HD 3D models, or even the best pixel art out there, there's something special about To The Moon's graphics. The pixel art still looks great, and the use of lighting at times is absolutely stunning. The way the colors become muted in some sections, while in other's they're vibrant and glowing is breathtaking at times, and always fitting of what's going on in the story. The music is also phenomenal, setting the atmosphere perfectly. There is one song in the game that has actual words that are sung, and this is the only voice acting in the whole game but it doesn't even matter since the song fits so perfectly with the sequence and the singing is so well done that it will most likely bring tears to your eyes. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

To The Moon is one of those games that will leave you thinking about it long after the final credits roll. If you're a fan of story driven games, it's absolutely a must play. There isn't tons of "gameplay" in it, with there being some quick puzzles and that's about it, but everything is so polished and well pieced together, that you can't help but be glued to the screen as the layers of this man's life are slowly peeled back piece by piece, with each layer exposing more and more. It's a game that will make you think, not only about Johnny's life but your own as well. Would you want to change the past to make a dream come true? Would you risk everything including those that you love for a chance at a dream? Would you want to look back at your own life in your dying breaths or would it be too painful to see the mistakes you've made? To The Moon is absolutely a game that you should play, and one that you won't want to put down. For more reviews, follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page. [/url]
