121582815.review:
It was an emotional journey. Brought a tear to my eye.

To the Moon is more of a narrative game. Usually just reading dialogues. But let that and the simple pixel style not discourage you because the story has so much depth and once you delve into it, you won't be able to quit.

We play the role of two doctors: Eva Rosalene and Neil Watts (my beloved clown) who specialise in altering the dying patient's memories in a way to grant their last biggest wish, which they didn't manage to fulfil. Johnny, the patient they visit in the featured game, desires to fly to the Moon as in the title. Except… he doesn't know why! This is a big impediment since our doctors need to know which aspect of life they should change in order to trigger the wish to happen. So there's nothing else for them to do than to traverse ALL his memories, from the latest to the earliest, until they reach the right part.

It is best and totally worth it to experience the story all for yourself. It is touching and will hit you hard but in a good way. And I must mention the music because it is phenomenal and makes a greater impact. To the Moon just proves that advanced graphics or mechanics aren't always the determinants of a true masterpiece. All it takes is a well-considered story and a memorable soundtrack.

121022414.review:
Let's be quite clear about one thing: there's not a lot of 'game' here. 

And that's just as well, because all us mooing, sausage-fingered brutes pawing our mice in the flickering light of better men's dreams could hope to achieve through gameplay would be to spoil perfection.

I've watched 'Up'. I've watched 'On Golden Pond'. I've watched THAT episode of Futurama, and I'm reasonably well-read to boot. To The Moon is, by a considerable margin, the most emotionally affecting piece of media it has ever been my privilege to experience. That it accomplishes this feat via RPGmaker and a handful of sprites is almost beside the point; it's like DaVinci was handed a crayon - what did you THINK was going to happen?

120428070.review:
This is by far the worst "Overwhelmingly Positive" game I've ever played. Somewhere in here is a poignant story told in an original way, and there is merit to that. HOWEVER:
1) The arbitrary nonsense I have to do to get the story to advance is infuriating and completely unnecessary. (Sorry, you need to go look at the empty dirt path before we can proceed)
2) The controls are clumsy, which amplifies the frustration of having to do arbitrary nonsense to get the story to advance (Sorry, you clicked on the wrong pixel)
3) The world makes no sense. There is no logic to how the memory world works, and the Doctors' abilities to operate inside that realm. It's mumbo-jumbo nonsense, and makes it impossible to be invested in the ridiculous things I have to do to unravel the story.
4) The doctors' constant cheesy "humor" hamfistedly distracts from the touching story
5) A lot of the writing is cliche and overwrought. Writers need editors.

The touching story inside is worthwhile, but would have been told much more effectively with a 15-minute movie presentation rather than making me do idiotic tasks for 5 hours.

120068132.review:
God...what to even say.

I loved this game. I'd never heard of it until last year, when RTgame played it. I watched the entire thing, then bought it for myself despite already knowing the story, and still loved it.

I love any story that toys with the concept of memories, and trying to put something so abstract into a tangible and understandable form. It's why The Giver is one of my favorite books. And I love the way everything is set up here. I love the characters, the story, the MUSIC! God, I've listened to this soundtrack so many times. It's beautiful. Everything Is Alright still makes me emotional, even if I've listened to it enough times that I don't cry anymore. 

Am I saying "love" too much? Sorry. I just can't think of a better word to describe it.

...Despite the fact that I only played this last November, this game is still incredibly personal to me. I had been questioning if I was on the autism spectrum for a long time, but never really went to get it tested. I always just assumed it was ADHD symptoms, or that I was being overly paranoid. However, while playing this game, I saw so much of myself in River. And the second verse to Everything Is Alright - the part that reflects River's thoughts - it was like hearing my own thoughts that I'd had all my life sung to me. Relatable and validating aren't strong enough words to describe it. I ended up getting an autism testing appointment several months later, and was diagnosed shortly after that. I'm not kidding when I say this game changed my life. I understand myself so much better now, and if it hadn't been for River or that beautiful song performed by Laura Shigihara, I might've never gotten to this point.

Thank you, Freebird Games, from the bottom of my heart.

119559587.review:
[h1] To the Moon Review[/h1]OK, now, this review is from someone who strongly dislikes RPGs. Whether it be the slow grind or confusing objectives, they are generally rather boring for me. To the Moon didn't truly change my perspective, but it is one of those games I can't give a bad review. The price, coming from a soul that played Portal 2 at the same price, is around twice what it should be (unless if you can afford $2.50 an hour for a short game). The graphics, well, you can't judge because of the size of the development team. In the store page, it says there is no combat whatsoever, which technically isn't true (Zombievas!). The gameplay is, well, what you would expect in most indie story-based games. The puzzles are easy and nice. Now, the story is obviously what the game is about, and it's the reason the game didn't flop. It's pretty good. I suppose I'm a heartless monster [spoiler](much like the old dying guy)[/spoiler], because I didn't cry my eyes out. More emotional people would, though. Perhaps another nice facet of To the Moon is the lack of any fillers, which make me tear my brains out. 
Overall, don't buy if you don't like RPGs and their narratives. Do buy if you like stuff like that.
Still probably wait for a sale.

119122707.review:
Click-and-point adventure games are constantly dismissed as boring, sappy, or whatever. And I avoided them for the longest time until I took a chance at To the Moon, interested in unique concept of a plot. No regrets.

To the Moon's two protagonists are funny, charming, and heartwarming, and have the weird ability to cheer up any player. And even if you're basically Hitty, the emotional aspects of the game don't flood the story enough to hurt it and Neil will jump in to complain about how sappy the situation is anyways. Even if you are sappy, though, gross, but also, you'll still find Neil funny. There's never a dull moment with him.

To the Moon isn't a game easily narrowed down to just someone who likes crying until they die of dehydration, or someone who likes games about being nosy. It's an interesting game with unique concepts that anyone who likes a good story can enjoy. In a game like this, you aren't just being told the story or being played a movie. You're being thrown into the shoes of the protagonists (ew?) and forced to endure the realization that this game capable of running on a Samsung smart grass seed easily outshines games with RTX that lack a memorable and meaningful story.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[*]Runs on an abacus
[*]Amazing characters
[*]No wasteful dialog. Every single line has meaning and is enjoyable
[*]Freebird Games explores unique concepts and thinks outside of the box, and it shows in games like this
[*]Good moozik and art
[*]Games that force you to think through difficult ethics are awesome. This is one, by the way. Finding Paradise is even more of one.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]No real settings menu. (Press F7 to change your language, then restart the game to avoid the bug where the momento prepare dialog stays in the old language. I wouldn't say the game is buggy at all, though)
[*]Sometimes, an interactable object important for progression will be right next to another one, making it hard to spot. Since the only way to identify them is by the cursor, it isn't immediately obvious that the object next to it is interactable and it's way easier to miss. It's a bit annoying, so keep this in mind while playing to avoid frustration
[*]No diagonal movement. I recommend moving with your mouse.
[/list]

[h1]Wishlist[/h1]
[list]
[*]Eight movable directions beats four (strength in numbers and all)
[*]Some visual hints at the objects needed for progression would be really handy. Finding Paradise had this but even then I don't think it applied to all progression objects.
[/list]

[b]In conclusion:[/b] There's nothing like playing a game that takes you through a unique story with unique concepts guided by two of the best characters ever. This game is a S-tier example for other studios to follow when coming up with their own adventure games. Not that they should copy the story or concept, but the choices of when to use dialog and what it should contribute, creating characters that have very different but very cool personalities, and a constantly-evolving and engaging story. The lack of settings, diagonal movement, or item indicators isn't nearly enough to ruin the story experienced through the game.

Linux users: You may need the Linux runtime. It's in your compatibility settings for the game at the bottom of the drop-down.

118532035.review:
I expected a much more emotional story than I experienced, but the story itself was still good, though you needed to really pay attention in order to understand the entirety of it.  Luckily, there's the internet to fill in the gaps in case you hurried through the game.

The game starts with two doctors going into Johnny's mind before he dies to try and review his memories to give him his final wish.  His wish was to go to the moon.  Throughout his memories you go backwards, from his oldest years down to his youngest years, which is a cool concept since you hear about events that happened in the past, but you haven't experienced yet, and then you do.  Eventually you learn who Johnny is, who is wife was, River, and about his family.  To say more would be to spoil it.

In each era of his memories you have to find things that trigger his memory so that you can move on to the next world.  Almost like finding the keycard that unlocks the next level.  So each memory level requires you to find 5 memories links that allow you to move on to the next level.  It is easy, and does not require much thinking or problem solving at all.

The game's graphics and sound are very simple almost like RPGMaker style graphics, but better.  However, it's not about the visual or sound effects in this game, it truly is about the world you explore and the story that you find unfolding backwards in Johnny's memories.  The music is good, not great, but King's Quest 4 type of good.  There are no voices, nothing special here, but simplistic pixel graphic gaming with simplistic controls.

While I expected a very emotional story that was meant to bring me to tears, as I read from other reviews, I found the story sweet, good, and easy to follow, but not something that hit me in the feels.  Still though, a decent idea for a story and well executed too.  So why not recommend the game.  If you like casual adventure games more a la exploration than puzzle solving, then try this, it'll only take you a few hours to complete and the story is worth a single playthrough to at least know that To The Moon is all about.

118172119.review:
[h1] I LIKE THIS GAME! I LOVE IT!! WILL I RECOMMEND IT? BIG FAT YES! BUT AM I SATISFIED AT ALL...? [/h1]

[b] Gameplay. [/b]
You gradually unlock the story by walking through each of the memories, and in each memory, you will bit by bit have a deeper insight of the characters by wandering in there. I had no problem with the gameplay and I really enjoyed it.

[b] Music [/b]
Gorgeous.

[b] Character [/b]
Beautiful.

[b] Story [/b]
The story had a very strong start which drew me into it right the moment I started. The progress of the story was very solid and I really enjoyed it, it bit by bit built up a bomb inside me (which I call an "emotion bomb"), the bomb then became really, really, really big, the bait was also attached and all it needed was a kick-starter. But... that kick-starter never happened.

It was at the time the knot started to be unknotted, I wasn't satisfied by how the story was resolved, it wasn't bad, but it... wasn't [i]that[/i] satisfying either, I can accept it, but it could have been done so much better. I can't blatantly tell you how the end of the story could have been, all I can say is that the author has just missed a BIG BIG chance to make this become sublime. Ju- just a bit more! I need [b] that moment[/b]! I can feel it! [b] I can f***ing feel it, Johnny[/b]!! JUST. A. BIT. MORE and that bomb would explode!! But, when the game reached the end screen where you press [ESC] to exit, all that left inside me was a mixing of sad, regret and a bit of disappointment. That moment I was waiting for never came, and that bomb couldn't, and never could, explode...

[h1] All In All! [/h1]
I don't regret playing this game, I enjoyed it really much and I had a lot of great moment with it. I also love the music, the characters, I love Dr. Eva, Dr. Neil, Lily, River, John, etc. and I love all the DLCs of the game, too (especially the comic DLC, [b]go get it if you haven't[/b]), but if you ask me if I were [b]really[/b] satisfied with the game, then... not really... I guess. But hey, it's still really good after all, though.

Okay, now this game I was hesitant on buying for awhile. I regret my hesitance horribly.
This game is one of the most beautiful, well written, emotional game I've ever played. I've read reviews saying all the stuff i'm about to say, but it seems I had underestimated all of it's wonderful features.

But now, 4 hours later, this first part is finished and I feel full but not whole. The sequel lies behead, and I hope it's better than this one. Such beautifully moving games.
Thank you to the creators for making such an emotional masterpiece. A 10/10 experience, and i can't wait to play the other games by them too!

To the moon is an emotional, thought-provoking title that almost had me in tears in the end. A tale about two “scientists” working on fulfilling a literal dying man’s wish.

The constant friendly-aggressive banter between Eva and Neill (the game’s main protagonists) is chuckle-inducing. I highly recommend if you are into games with a heavy drive on narrative and good music.

116814036.review:
This game caught my eye, then stayed with me for years. I've read it was made with RPG-maker, which has arguably simple SNES-like graphics. I usually like 3D games with lots of freedom of movement so this game was something different than what I normally would play. But I heard it was well written and emotionally moving, especially for a game made with RPG-maker so I was intrigued. I've played triple A games that looked incredible but had no soul to it, no meaningful story or uniqueness to them. And I've played older games with simpler graphics that really made an impact on me. 

So basically I wanted to play this game to see if such a 'simple' game could have a profound effect on me. I wanted to experience if this game could tell a story as powerful as some next-gen HD cinematic games can. And the answer is yes! The topics of this game (family, autism, dreams) really spoke to me and the story felt relatable. At first I thought that some themes in the game were a bit random or cliché but later in the game these themes recur and get more weight to them. I've played the game 2 times (about 3 years apart) and I'm only just now getting a rather clear picture of the whole story. There's still one or two questions unanswerd but maybe I'll play it again in another 3 years and I'll get the whole story then. Since you go through the whole story backwards and are traversing through memories and virtual constructs of one's mind, this game will peak your interest if you like movies such as Memento, Inception and maybe even The Matrix. It's not a real sci-fi game but has some of those elements in it, without them becoming gimmicks. At first the story is simple but later on you réally start connecting the dots and that makes the whole story more meaningful. 

I've played this game to experience something. I don't think a game is just it's graphics or gameplay. It's also the experience you get from it while playing it. I think if you're an insensitive son of a &#%&$ you might resonate less with the themes of the story. But if you like somewhat romantic stories about growing up, family, love, dreams and destiny you might really like this one. I feel that particularly older games with simpler graphics have something that next-gen really graphical games don't have: they leave room for imagination. Because the characters in this RPG are simple pixelated sprites, my imagination automatically thought they looked like people I know in real life. And being able to project something of your own unto a game is only possible if the game uses relatable themes and dialogue. And it does. So that also made the game much more personal to me. Also the music is very atmospheric and the piano theme that's featured throughout the whole game will probably always stay with me. 

I think the only gripe people could have with this game is that it's relatively short and you could probably speed run this game in a few hours. But since the game probably costs even less than $10,- at the time you read this review, I'd say, go for it. Take the time to let it all in and saviour the experience. Triple A games can learn from the storytelling this game offers and I wish more people will discover this gem of a game!

To begin, you need to know two things to know before you play. First is the game has no graphical options whatsoever, it will play in 480p fullscreen and you will like it! Second is there is no audio options either, just use Windows audio mixer to adjust the volume for the program if you need to.

116217412.review:
I completely agree with all of the other negative reviews. "To The Moon" is a decent story wrapped up in an awful game. I swear, if I see one more door that says "unlock 3 more memory orbs to proceed," I'm going to slam my head into my desk. I'd happily click through the dialogue, jumping immediately from one scene to the next. Instead, I have to walk slowly and clumsily (the controls are terrible) across the same maze of a map just to find which objects in the room are clickable, to then be granted a memory orb (is this supposed to give a sense of accomplishment or something?). It seems the developers added in this "mechanic" in an attempt to make the game more engaging, but after 3-4 hours of the exact same thing, I found myself just begging for the game to end already. And don't even get me started about the side-scroller/shooter phase...

Clearly, I seem to be an outlier as most people left positive reviews, but this game really irritated me more than it should. "To The Moon" has a fair bit of potential, but the developers had to go in and ruin it with repetitive mechanics just for the sake of calling it a "game". I think most people would be much better off watching a play through vs suffering through the "gameplay" themselves. Let someone else handle the chore of fighting the controls for 4 hours and just sit back and enjoy the story.

Let's get the basics out of the way before I get onto emotional importance. It's a good game with good sprite animations and work for the rpgmaker engine build it appears to be based on. There's little movements in the sprites I really like, eg the eyes. And I feel the story is well written and easy to understand and easy to say 
"Okay we can go into a person's head and change their memories, got it, let's go"

Maybe spoilers:
Now for the meat of this review I might call it. The first place I was saw this game was just under a decade ago, on the now kinda love-hated Pewdiepie channel. It caught my attention quickly with the character writing and kept me watching, most importantly up to the part about River. River is the first time I felt represented in a video game or maybe even in media. She's a woman with what seems to be high functioning autism also known as Asperger's syndrome. This meant a lot to me as a teenage girl with the disorder cause she just felt right. Like I related to the way she acted and moved and I felt happy. Even years later I still cry at the end, cause I care so much about the characters. I love this game.

Great story! Even cried a little near the end!

RPG Maker type gameplay and pixel graphics, but without any combat. Just story and exploration/interaction based puzzles.

100% in 4 1/2 hours. (Only one achievement, and it's for completing the game.)

115997476.review:
Games that make you cry always hold special places in our hearts. They may not have been the most fun to play, nor being close to our favourite, but the fact that they somehow managed to reach to our feelings deeply enough to provoke a physical reaction creates a very special relationship with them, that overthrows in our mind every kind of issues we may have had along the way. 

Thank you so much Kan Gao, Laura Shigahara and every creators who participated of making this game

115945661.review: A wonderful, touching story with beautiful scenery and music. I loved it!

115930079.review: to the moon is such a heartfelt, story-focused game, it’s one of the few games that actually made me cry. it’s a 16-bit rpg-like format which is nostalgic & aesthetically pleasing. the music very repetitive, but the main piano-theme is very catchy & gets stuck in your head. again, the story is incredibly powerful & really hits home for me; even tho i wouldn’t replay it all over again, there’s parts that still stick with me to this day. it really makes you reflect on your own life, your regrets, & makes you wonder what would you change if you could.
